He wanted to videotape and record Father Mella’s works. Last Friday Lenny organised a mini-concert of Father Mella's works in an industrial building in Kwai Chung.

Title: Hong Kong Polytechnic University Finances Under Criticism
Content description: The management of Hong Kong’s largest technical educational institution, the Polytechnic University, is facing many questions. According to its latest financial report the university had a deficit of $900 million last year, while over a hundred senior staff were still receiving generous annual salaries of $1.8 million to $4.8 million. Half of the loss was incurred by the sale of university investments that included high-risk stocks and derivatives. There are questions about why, in recent years, the institution shifted from more conservative investments.There are still further questions about the 38 companies set up by the university, many of which are in the red.

Title: More HOS Flats?
Content description: Property prices are on the up again. And most people’s salaries haven’t been rising to keep up. Things have reached a stage where even property developers and bankers, for so long arguing against government intervention in the market, are now saying that maybe it’s time for new Home Ownership Scheme flats to be built.

Title: Forced Sale of Old Buildings
Content description: In January, without prior discussion with legislators, the government gazetted legislation that will make it easier for developers to acquire older properties. With effect from April 1st, those developers can seek a compulsory sale from the Lands Tribunal as soon as they’ve acquired ownership of 80% of an old property rather than the present 90%.

Title: Protest in Bangkok
Content description: After several days, the protests in Bangkok are dying down. Many of those who have come to the capital to air their grievances are from rural areas and have to return to their jobs and businesses. Others in the latest campaign, organised by the United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship, have vowed they will stay on the streets despite dwindling numbers.They say they will continue to push prime minister Abhisit Vejajjiva to step down. The anti-government protesters, also known as the “red shirts”, are supporters of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra who was ousted in a military coup in 2006. During the current campaign the protesters used their own blood to make their points, collecting thousand of litres of to splatter on Government House, the headquarters of the ruling Democrat Party, and the residence of Thai Prime Minister Abhisit. Mr Abhisit insists he will not give in to their demands but is open to dialogue.  With us in the studio to discuss the situation are Professor William Case from the Southeast Asia Research Centre of the Department of Asian and International Studies at City University, and Hugo Restall from the Wall Street Journal Asia.

Title: Student Suicides
Content description: On the Monday before our broadcast, the body of a mainland Chinese student was found at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. She was the third student at the institution to have committed suicide in the past 18 months. Three university students have killed themselves in Hong Kong in just over two weeks, since the beginning of March.

Title: Street Sleepers- Younger and more Educated
Content description: It’s common as you get older to begin to think that policeman and doctors are getting younger. If you are starting to find that even Hong Kong’s street sleepers are not as old as they used to be, or as uneducated, you may be right. A recent survey highlights that the recent economic crisis, low wages, and family problems, are sending many people onto the streets younger.

Title: Air Pollution Breaks a Record
Content description: Fresh air in Hong Kong is beginning to feel like a luxury. On Monday the Air Pollution Index or API went off the charts. It hit the maximum 500 again on Tuesday. An API of 200 is already considered hazardous to health.

Title: The Rio Tinto Trial
Content description:
A verdict’s expected on Monday in the trial of four employees of the Chinese branch of an Australian mining firm, Rio Tinto. The trial was adjourned on Wednesday at the Shanghai No. 1 Intermediate People's Court to wait for a decision. Overseas companies operating in China, and overseas governments, are watching the case closely.

With us in the studio to discuss why are Janet da Silva of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, and Leslie Hook of the Wall Street Journal.

Title: Public Broadcasting Proposals
Content description: The day before our broadcast the government published a draft charter for the future of Radio Television Hong Kong, according to which the broadcaster will be editorially independent, and have a 'broad-based' board of appointed advisers. That’s probably the most contentious part of the charter, and has led to some concern that the board will impinge on the station’s editorial independence. Meanwhile this week, RTHK invited a group of international public broadcasters to talk about the nature of public broadcasting in their countries. They spoke to The Pulse.

Title: Adulterated Chinese Medicine
Content description: So far this year the Department of Health has issued five recall orders for Chinese medical preparations, most recently for Po Chai pills. Western pharmaceuticals had been added in all five cases. In the United States, ongoing tests on Chinese medical preparations have found dozens of products containing toxic levels of arsenic, mercury, or lead, or unacknowledged western drugs. In 2009, the Hong Kong Department of Health tested 2,700 samples and found about 2% contained Western medicines or excessive heavy metals. Some say the problem has worsened as more new companies spring up on the mainland.

Title: Death Sentences in China
Content description: Last year, at least 714 people were executed in 18 countries and at least 2,001 sentenced to death, in 56 countries. That’s according to the latest Amnesty International report “Death Sentences and Executions in 2009”. Amnesty believes thousands more executions took place in China, but refuses to estimate an actual figure in protest against the country’s secrecy over just how many of its citizens it kills. With us in the studio to discuss this is Amnesty International’s Roseann Rife and cultural commentator Chan Wan.

Title: Against Shark Fin Soup
Content description:
In part one of tonight's show, we look at shark finning and the issue of marine sustainability. Hong Kong internet users were recently shocked by footage shot by local tourists showing a whale shark that had had its fins removed and been left to die on a beach in the Philippines. It has led to increasing momentum in campaigns to discourage people from consuming shark fin soup, a staple of many Chinese banquets. But even though demand is going down in Hong Kong, it is increasing in mainland China. Meanwhile Japan seems to remain determined to block almost every attempt to preserve marine species. 

We also talk to Professor Yvonne Sadovy about marine sustainability.

Title: Social Harmony in HK?
Content description: According to a recent survey by the Chinese University of Hong Kong’s Institute of Asia-Pacific Studies, only 26.5% of respondents find Hong Kong to be a harmonious society, a sharp drop of 11% over a previous poll two years ago. And an increasing number say they can understand or condone more extreme social activism.

Title: Political Reform Proposal
Content description:
On Wednesday, the Hong Kong government and the central government took a series of steps to try to gain Hong Kong people’s support for the 2012 Constitutional Reform Proposal. However, to the dismay of many, the proposal contains none of the major changes from the blueprint that the pro-democrats had requested. There is no assurance asked on abolishing the functional constituencies and no full roadmap to universal suffrage.

With us in the studio to discuss this are legislators Ronny Tong of the Civic Party and Philip Wong from the Commerce Functional Constituency.

Title: Legislators discuss the future PSB
Content description: Last September, the administration announced that RTHK is to remain a government department and continue to provide public service broadcasting. It also wants to introduce a charter to entrench RTHK’s independence and to install a 15-member board of advisers selected by the Chief Executive. This week, legislators discussed the proposal.

Title: May By-Elections
Content description: The day before our broadcast, legislators passed funding for the May 16th by-election triggered by the resignation of pro-democracy activists, much to the annoyance of pro-Beijing members. Pro-democracy figures say they want the May 16th by-elections to be seen as a de facto referendum on constitutional reform.It was thought the elections, triggered by the resignation of legislators from the Civic Party and the League of social Democrats, would be poorly contested.There are now 24 registered eligible candidates. Complementing the aims of the five former legislators, five students from a group called Tertiary 2012 say they share the same goal of striving for universal suffrage and scrapping functional constituencies.

Title: Toy Banks
Content description: According to Article 31 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children, every child should have the rights of rest, leisure, recreation and cultural and artistic activities. Without such opportunities, they could be caught in a cycle of poverty that will pass from generation to generation. Toy banks aim to provide children of underprivileged families with some of that necessary recreation by giving them something to play with. And Hong Kong has two organisations that provide toy banks for its needy children.

Title: A New Tax on Global Banks
Content description: News reports this week say that the International Monetary Fund is encouraging the G20 nations to tax bank profits and executive salaries of their employees to prevent another financial crisis, or to fund future bailouts. Meanwhile in the United States, a similar proposal in President Obama’s suggested financial reforms seems to be falling by the wayside as neither Democrats nor Republicans think it’s a good idea. Will such a safety net, as some fear, encourage bankers to take too many risks? With us in the studio to discuss this is Hugo Restall of the Wall Street Journal.

Title: Yushu Earthquake Relief
Content description: As of Sunday evening, officials say some 2,200 had been killed in the earthquake that hit the remote Tibetan area of Yushu on April 14. Reconstruction work will begin next Tuesday. But efforts to help those affected by the earthquake have been hindered by the remoteness of the region, its altitude, and by political tensions. One organisation working in the region is Oxfam and we have its Hong Kong director John Sayer in the studio with us.

Title: Stop Idling Engines
Content description:
It’s been ten years since a law to band idling vehicle engines was first proposed in Hong Kong. But as the air quality has continued to deteriorate, underlined by exceptionally high levels of air pollution this week, there’s a new impetus to introduce tough measures. Some are delighted. Others less so. 

But even as legislators discussed the proposal this week, one longtime clean air campaigner Professor Anthony Hedley. is leaving Hong Kong. The air is harmful to his health.

Title: Pastors and Politics
Content description: It’s often said that life is a lot more harmonious if you never get into arguments about politics, or about religion. It’s probably a lot less harmonious when the two coincide. But how appropriate is it for religious organisations themselves to get into political arguments, whether supporting the establishment or against it?

Title: Paid Political Radio
Content description: The day before our show, members of the League of Social Democrats and a group called Speak-Up Hong Kong handed in more than 1,000 complaints letters to the Broadcasting Authority.They were complaining about Commercial Radio’s acceptance of around $500,000 in sponsorship for one particular programme from the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong. They say the sponsorship is testing how serious the government is about restrictions on paid political advertising.

Title: Animal Cruelty
Content description: Two weeks ago, Chinese newspapers in Hong Kong featured an appalling and deliberate act of animal cruelty. For years now, a dog poisoner, or multiple poisoners, have been killing pets on Bowen Road and around mid-levels. Unfortunately, you can see plenty more acts of cruelty in Hong Kong’s wet markets. Some cruelty to animals is the result of ignorance. In other cases, it is the result of mental disorder. But does society actually care enough to deal with it?

Title: The UK Elections
Content description: Has the face of British politics been changed by this week's UK elections? Yes, Gordon Brown’s Labour government has been unpopular of late, so a swing towards the Conservatives was expected. The Liberal Democrats and Nick Clegg didn't do as well as expected, but they will play a pivotal role in the new government. But, given the state of the European economy, should anyone want to win, particularly without a clear majority? With us in the studio are Tom Holland of the South China Morning Post and Richard Harris of Conservatives Abroad.

Title: Affordable Housing?
Content description: Amid the growing public demand for resuming sales of HOS flats, Secretary for Transport and Housing Eva Cheng recently wrote in a Chinese-language newspaper that although the government has the responsibility to make sure everyone has somewhere to live, it has no obligation to ensure every family has its own property. She also said that the Home Ownership Scheme is not the only option for first time buyers, and questioned whether taxpayers’ money should be used to help people become flat owners. But the administration says it will revisit its flat policy

Title: By-Election Preview
Content description: Call it a by-election, call it a referendum, people will be going out to vote on the Sunday after our broadcast. The government and the pro-Beijing parties are playing it down. Others are determined to get as many out to vote as possible. Pro-establishment forces are remaining mum on the issue. We asked Legco president Tsang Yok-sing for an interview. His assistant said he has “no plan to take any interview over the by-elections issue.” We asked the DAB, the Liberal Party, and a couple of those who designate themselves independents. No luck there either. Maybe if they don’t talk about it, it will go away. However, in our studio and willing to talk about the by-elections are Edward Yam, Convenor of Speak Up HK, and Joseph Cheng, Professor of Political Science at City University.

Title: Charity Collectors? Are They Genuine?
Content description: If you have any spare cash after paying your mortgage or rent, you may consider giving a little to charity. But there seem to be more and more people asking for donations on the streets these days. And how do you know if any of them are genuine?

Title: Studio Discussion - What Next After the By-Election?
Content description: In the wake of the by-election, the government has set its sights on pushing the 2012 electoral reforms, some pro-democrats have hopes of talking to mainland representatives, and the Chief Executive wants a public debate with the Civic Party’s Audrey Eu. But has the democratic camp been strengthened or weakened by last weekend’s vote? With us in the studio are Leung Kwok-hung of the League of Social Democrats, the Civic Party’s Alan Leong, Frederick Fung of the Association for Democracy and People's Livelihood, and executive councillor Leong Che-hung.

Title: By-Election - The Student Candidates
Content description:
The by-election, or de-facto referendum is over, the five resignees have once again been sworn in as legislators, and the government has gone on the road to put the case for its 2012 constitutional reforms.

So was there any point to the whole exercise? Has it strengthened or weakened the bonds between pan-democrats? Or improved the chances of gaining any concessions from the authorities? That’s the focus of tonight’s show.

This by-election was marked by the increased participation of young voters, and we begin by talking to the five students who ran as candidates.

Title: Voting - A Civic Responsibility?
Content description: The Registration and Electoral Office asked voters to: "Please exercise your civic rights and fulfill your civic responsibilities by casting your vote in the by-election". Notably, our government leaders decided not to do so. Mixed messages on the democratic process? Many complained about the half-hearted election arrangements.

Title: Journalists Assaulted on Prayer Day
Content description: In Hong Kong, last Sunday's Global Day of Prayer took place. Among the more than 10,000 Christians in the Hong Kong Stadium, 20 protesters from the “Alliance of Back to Christ” also wanted to pray: for jailed social activists in China such as Liu Xiaobo, for victims of the “bean curd school buildings” in the Sichuan earthquake, and for those killed or injured on June 4th 1989. Instead, they were, they said, physically abused by event volunteers. As were some of the journalists covering their activities.

Title: Electoral Reforms - What HK Government?
Content description: Mainland officials have finally agreed to talk to pro-democracy figures, well some of them anyway. The Chief Executive Donald Tsang has also agreed to debate the Civic Party’s Audrey Eu on the 2012 constitutional reforms. But has the Hong Kong government been sidelined, giving the liaison office too much prominence in the political scene, and is that Hong Kong government misjudging the sentiments of the people? With us in the studio are the former leader of the Democratic Party Martin Lee, and Chris Yeung of the Hong Kong Economic Journal.

Title: Interactive Visualisation Lab
Content description: It’s AliVE, or in its full form, the Applied Laboratory for Interactive Visualization and Embodiment. It’s been set up by the City University of Hong Kong as an incubator and innovation showcase for new forms of creativity. The laboratory will be fully launched on 25th June, but this week, the newly appointed Dean of the School of Creative Media, Jeffrey Shaw, gave the media a preview.

Title: Minorities and the Media
Content description: Hong Kong’s minorities don’t often see themselves, or their lives, reflected in its media. Or if they do, they tend to be shown in stereotyped if not derogatory fashion. This week, they were telling lawmakers what they are hoping for from Hong Kong’s future public broadcaster.

Title: That "Act Now" PR Campaign
Content description: The day after our programme goes to air government ministers will be taking to the streets again, as they did the previous weekend, to convince Hong Kong people to “Act Now” on constitutional reform. Last weekend they were strangely coy about telling the media where they were going, but we have heard that this time they won’t be quite so shy. But will it work? We talk to two public relations consultants about the campaign.

Title: Confrontation at Times Square
Content description: It’s June 4th. That anniversary. And activists have already run into problems while wanting to commemorate the events of 21 years ago. On Wednesday, the police returned the two statues and a relief sculpture, confiscated last weekend, to the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Movements of China. Last Saturday, the Alliance took the works to Times Square. When they arrived with the statues at 11a.m., they were confronted by more than 80 police officers. Officers from the Food and Environment Hygiene Department told the Alliance that it was breaching the law by displaying the exhibits without an entertainment license. They wanted the sculptures moved. When the protesters refused, the department confiscated them.

Title: Hate Speech
Content description:
Last week the Equal Opportunities Commission expressed its concern over internet messages that it felt incited racial hatred. Under the Race Discrimination Ordinance it’s against the law to discriminate, harass or vilify a person on the ground of the person’s race. Doing so can bring a maximum penalty of $100,000 and imprisonment for two years. The commission also approached the concerned blog masters and ISPs informing them of possible liabilities. The website companies were urged to remove the derogatory contents and to provide information on the individual bloggers. Unfortunately material showing contempt or hatred for other groups is far from rare on the internet. But who draws the line? And where?

With us in the studio are the Chairperson of the Equal Opportunities Commission, Lam Woon-kwong, Francis Fong, founder of the Internet Society, and Joe Yau of the Hong Kong Baptist University.

Title: That "Act Now" Campaign
Content description: Nine million dollars. That’s how much the government’s campaign to tell you to Act Now on constitutional reform has cost. The government says the Act Now TV spots are not political advertisements. Ironically, a very similar spot produced by the Civic Party has been refused broadcast by TVB. Why? It’s supposedly a political advertisement.

Title: Foxconn Suicides
Content description: he Foxconn Technology Group, which has recently been in the news after a series of worker suicides at its compound in Shenzhen, said yesterday it may consider moving some of its production lines back to Taiwan. In other words if labour costs too much in China, we’re going home. There’s been controversy over whether conditions at the plant were unduly harsh.

Title: CE/Audrey Eu Debate
Content description: The big political event of this week in Hong Kong was the debate between Chief Executive Donald Tsang and legislator Audrey Eu on constitutional reform. According to news media, commentators, and opinion polls, most felt it did not go well for the Chief Executive. We review the event with the help of political scientist James Sung.

Title: Leak in Daya Bay Nuclear Power Plant
Content description: The Chinese government and China Light and Power have played down worries over recent reports of a radiation leak at the Daya Bay nuclear power plant. Some sources are arguing such fuel rod leaks are common. Another, quoted in today’s papers, says they have not been common for fifty years. But what say does Hong Kong have in operations at the plant anyway?

Title: Debate - The View Outside Legco
Content description: Security was tight around the Central Government Offices where the debate was taking place to keep out protesters. Instead, many of those interested watched from outside the Legislative Council building where it was relayed live. Audrey Eu visited the scene both before and after the event.

Title: Legco Debate and Vote on Constitutional Reforms
Content description:
It’s been a historic week for Hong Kong, although – putting the political rhetoric aside for the moment – it’ll be a while before we know whether it’s a giant step forward or something else entirely. 

Whatever happens after the reforms go through, it is likely to be less significant than some of the events that have led up to the vote. For one thing, Beijing has negotiated with the Democratic Party, which it formerly ostracised.

On the other hand, the Democratic camp is divided. 

Under the government’s 2012 proposals there will be ten more seats in the Legislative Council. Five will be directly elected from geographical constituencies, five from District Council functional constituencies.The Democratic Party’s compromise, accepted by Beijing, is that around three million voters will directly elect representatives of the new District Council constituencies, although they will be nominated by, and from the ranks of, already elected councillors.

The three day Legco debate on the reforms was often contentious.

Title: The Pro-Democrat Split
Content description: On the other side of the Legco building, and largely kept apart from pro-government demonstrators by police, pro-democracy protesters were not directing ALL their anger at government officials or pro-government legislators. Many were furious at the Democratic Party.

Title: Pro-Reform Rallies
Content description: Over the past few weeks, pan-democrats have been organising demonstrations against the 2012 package. Government officials have also been out on the street telling people to Act Now. Over the past seven days, the pro-Beijing organisations have been determined to show democrats they aren’t the only ones who can draw a crowd, even if it has to be "encouraged" to come.

Title: Democratic Infighting 2
Content description: In Part Two of the show, where does an apparently deeply divided pro-democracy alliance go from here? With us in the studio are the Democratic Party’s James To, the Civic Party’s Ronny Tong, and Cyd Ho of Civic Act-Up.

Title: Democratic Infighting 1
Content description:
Tonight we’re looking at the fortunes of the pro-democracy movement.

After the Democratic Party supported the government’s 2012 Constitutional Reform package last week, many who formerly identified with the party have felt cheated.Yesterday, the Democratic Party, a founder and leader of the July 1st demonstrations, found itself the target of much criticism at this year's march.

Title: Hong Kong's dwindling freedom of speech
Content description: Last week, legislators held a motion debate on whether freedom of speech is becoming more tightly restricted in Hong Kong. On Saturday, the Hong Kong Journalists’ Association released a report that said it was. Government attempts to hinder pro-democracy demonstrations at Times Square, and elsewhere, featured in both discussions.

Title: China;'s Media Mouthpieces
Content description: Two weeks ago, the Hong Kong Journalists’ Association collaborated with a film company to organise a workshop on press freedom and the free flow of information, or lack of it, in mainland China. Two documentary film directors were invited to share their experience and show excerpts from their works. The three-hour documentary, “Mouthpiece” was directed by Guo Xizhi. Having worked in the state media himself, Guo Xizhi was part of the establishment.

Title: A Questionable Deal?
Content description: In March, to convince sceptics that reports of sales of 24 flats at 39 Conduit Road were genuine, Henderson Land’s chairman Lee Shau-kee offered a 100-to-one wager.One flat had featured the world’s most expensive floor area at HK$88,000 a square foot. Even more questions have been raised now that 20 of the 24 reported transactions have fallen through. and Henderson has not demanded the buyers pay the full deposit. So was this market manipulation?

Title: Minimum Wage - At last
Content description: It has taken a long time, but the Hong Kong government has finally agreed to minimum wage legislation. However, concerns were expressed this week that it may do little to help some of society’s most disadvantaged people. It could bring problems for social enterprises and for the disabled.

Title: Green Roofs
Content description: While there is still denial in some quarters over whether global warming actually exists, the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies recently announced that the global surface temperature in 2010 has already reached record levels. As temperatures rise, we use more power, and release more carbon dioxide, which in turn makes the world a hotter place. One way of breaking that circle could also bring a little green into your life. Give yourself a green rooftop.

Title: Street Performers
Content description: The Legco chamber isn’t the only place you can see free performances, dramatic or otherwise. Hong Kong also has a small but enthusiastic group of street performers without political aspirations, although some argue that compared with other tourist destinations, the government here seems unsure about entertainment in the street.On Tuesday, Civic Party legislator Alan Leong arranged a media presentation at Mongkok pedestrian zone to highlight the plight of street performers, some of whom say they have been unfairly prosecuted. It’s a longstanding problem.

Title: Chief Executive vs LSD
Content description: It’s likely that the Chief Executive views his Question and Answer sessions in the Legislative Council with some trepidation. This week, yet again, there were moments when it turned into a showdown with members of the League of Social Democrats.

Title: The Fight for Tai Long Sai Wan
Content description: Tai Long Sai Wan is one of Hong Kong's most beautiful beaches. Now one millionaire is planning to develop it, and has already left scars on the landscape.

Title: Health Care Reform
Content description: The major diseases of modern societies are chronic diseases, often brought on by lifestyle. Improved primary health care may head many of them off. After decades of talking about it, the government is attempting to improve primary health care, but private doctors are less than enthusiastic.

Title: Do we Need Freedom of Information Legislation?
Content description: As we know, governments spend our money. In many places, they are also elected by and answerable to their people. For us to know how well they are doing, or have done their job, we need access to government records, and most advanced places have Freedom of Information acts to allow public and journalistic access to government papers. Hong Kong does not.

Title: Expansion of SENT Landfill
Content description: The government is extending the SENT Landfill area, including designating about five hectares of land in Clear Water Bay Country Park and about 15.6 hectares of land in Tseung Kwan O Area 137. Many local residents are complaining it will have an adverse impact on them, the environment (in terms of odour and visual impact), traffic, and their health.

Title: China and Hong Kong Overfishing
Content description: There’s an ongoing campaign to reduce the consumption of shark fin. Vivian Lam and Yvonne Sadovy, of the University of Hong Kong, have used historical information and interviews with modern fishermen to produce the first historical account of the region’s shark catch, released just last week.Although there are 109 species of shark historically present in the South China Sea, surveys of today’s markets found just 18 species. Of those animals that were found, 65% were below the size of sexual maturity. All those interviewed in the study highlighted a drastic decline in shark abundance and diversity, as well as of other fish species. They also said they had to travel further and fish harder to obtain the same amount of fish esh. Basking sharks and larger requiem sharks may even have been made locally extinct.

Title: The Genuine Fake Gold Shop Closes - Lo Shut
Content description: Closure of Lo Shut imitation gold shop, which has been operating for more than 80 years in Yau Ma Tei. It’s name means “honesty” and it sold chu yee sing, better known as imitation gold jewelry, and other handmade items. Owner Mok Kam-chung, 77, has operated the shop on Reclamation Street since he was 19, having inherited it from his father, who started the business in 1926.

Title: Public Information - Chinese Only
Content description: If you’re a regular viewer of The Pulse, you’ll know that we regularly ask for government spokespersons to come onto the show. You’ll also know that we often get fobbed off with a written reply. Quite often, although we’re an English-language show, asking questions in English, that reply comes in Chinese only, as do an increasing number of press releases. Even when they are aimed at minorities. The HKJA has done a study of the government's declining willingness to speak English.

Title: Health Reform Proposals
Content description: This week a pile of garbage threatened to become a constitutional crisis as legislators and officials butted heads over expanding a New Territories landfill. That’s now been delayed if not necessarily averted. But if the health of the political system might be a little shaky right now, the government’s hoping that a new initiative will improve the health of its citizens. We look at the proposed medical reforms and interview the Deputy Secretary for Food and Health, Thomas Chan, in our studio.

Title: The "Luxury Flat" Racket
Content description: In the past year, the prices of luxury homes have jumped 18% to an average $18,500 per square foot. Investors are bullish, even as many of the less well off are finding themselves priced out of the housing market. But what defines these luxury properties?They aren’t always in high-end locations, but whatever location they are in, they try to stand out through such features as balconies, podium car parks, grand clubhouses and glamorous lobbies. These are considered “exempted environmental features”, which means they are not included in the officially approved gross floor area. They can take up a lot of space. Meanwhile, behind the glitz, the units themselves are often pretty small. Despite that, the buyers are there.

Title: World Poverty
Content description: In Part Two, we look at world poverty with Oxfam's Frank Elvey. One in every two of the world’s children - 1 billion children) - live in poverty. In 2009 alone, just over eight million died before they reached the age of five. One dies every three seconds. Sunday is the “International Day for the Eradication of Poverty”. The theme this year is "From Poverty to Decent Work: bridging the gap".

Title: Bicycling in Hong Kong?
Content description: It’s clean, it’s non-polluting, it’s healthy, as long as you don’t get killed or injured while trying to do it on Hong Kong’s roads. I’m talking about cycling. There are a hardy few who actually try to ride bicycles to work. Others ride them for sport on the weekends. But biking fans say that Hong Kong seems uninterested in making biking either popular or safe.

Title: Donald Tsang's Sixth Policy Address
Content description:
In his sixth Policy Address, Chief Executive Donald Tsang insisted he would not be leading a lame-duck administration. Livelihood issues are the community’s principal concerns and will be his focus for the remaining two years in office. Housing, the wealth gap, and the welfare of the elderly were major topics. 

On a political note, he said that after repeated deliberations, his administration had decided not to legislate under Basic Law Article 23 during the current term.

Title: Policy Address Discussion
Content description: With us in the studio to discuss the Address are Professor Michael Davis of the Chinese University of Hong Kong and Fernando Cheung of the Hong Kong Polytechnic University.

Title: The Pulse  22-10-10
Content description: China's foreign relations

Title: The MPF - Not Ideal for Retirement?
Content description: The Mandatory Provident Fund was introduced to make better provision for the elderly. For many, it’s a case of too little too late, and high management fees. As a result it may well not be the best option for a secure retirement.

Title: Discrimination Against Men?
Content description:
It’s the tough guy syndrome. Men, when faced with problems, should just suck it up, grit their teeth and move on. While there is an increasing amount of social support for women, traditional attitudes are that the male just shouldn’t need such namby pamby support. Now however the Equal Opportunities Commission is launching a six-month study into some of the difficulties faced by men. 

With us in the studio to talk about the commission's work is its Chairperson Lam Woon-kwong.

Title: Housing - The Bubble Still Growing
Content description: Chief Executive Donald Tsang’s Sixth Policy Address was supposed to dampen property speculation. The weekend after he delivered it, property sales went up, and the bubble’s still growing. Now even the secondary market for some old housing estate flats and Home Ownership Scheme properties is heating up. What used to be opportunities for first time buyers are now beyond their price range, as in Tuen Mun.

Title: 5th Eco Expo Asia
Content description: Visitors from around 20 countries are in Hong Kong this week to look for environmentally friendly technology, systems and products they can integrate into their business operations. It’s the 5th Eco Expo Asia. We report on some of the ideas on show.

Title: Animal-Friendly Hong Kong?
Content description: This week, legislators, some of them anyway, debated a motion to urge the Central Government to release Nobel Peace prize winner Liu Xiaobo and all political dissidents. The predictable faces, and voices, were noticeable by their absence, although they did return to vote the motion down. Rather more widely discussed, and more popular with even pro-Beijing legislators, was a motion by the DAB’s Chan Hak-kan to develop a more animal friendly policy in Hong Kong.

Title: US Mid-Term Elections Discussion
Content description: Historically first-term United States’ presidents can expect a mid-term reversal, but the smack in the nose suffered by US Democrats this week is one of the sharpest reversals in decades. Miscalculation on the part of President Obama and his team? Or the inevitable results of an economic situation they were bequeathed. And what fallout might the possibly gridlocked US system have on the rest of the world? With us in the studio to discuss this are Glenn Shive of the Hong Kong America Center at the Chinese University of Hong Kong and Michael De Golyer of the Department of Government and International Studies at Hong Kong Baptist University.

Title: Minimum Wage Set
Content description:
After many years of wrangling, Hong Kong is going to have a minimum wage. On Tuesday, Executive Council Members approved the Provisional Minimum Wage Commission’s recommendation to set Hong Kong’s first statutory minimum wage at $28 per hour. The Provisional Minimum Wage Commission says that 40,000 workers could lose their jobs as a result of the minimum wage. Some employers warn that their product or service prices will rise. Other employers say they may have to close down some of their outlets. But an increasing number of economists argue that these are not automatic results of minimum wage legislation.

With us in the studio is legislator Lee Cheuk-yan who is also General Secretary of the Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions.

Title: New Insurance Demands for Filipino Workers;Small Class Sizes
Part Two
Content description:
Slimming and Fitness Programmes - For Your Wallet

Losing Weight Can be Hazardous to Your Health

Title: Part One
Content description: Mainland Inflation and the Elderly

Title: Part Two
Content description: Hong Kong's Growing Wealth Gap (Part Two)

Title: Part One
Content description: Hong Kong's Growing Wealth Gap

Title: Global Warming
Content description: In Cancun, Mexico, representatives of close to 200 countries are attending a UN conference on global warming. Major progress is not expected. Activists say the prospects for even modest progress in Cancun are small. Despite resistance in some quarters, the majority of climate scientists believe that global warming is the greatest danger facing humans in the 21st century. In Hong Kong over the past week, climate issues have also been much under discussion. The government’s consultation on Hong Kong’s response to climate change ends next Friday.

Title: Do We Want the Asian Games?
Content description: This year’s Asian Games in Guangzhou reportedly cost over HK$150 billion to host. The Hong Kong government reckons it could do it for quite a bit cheaper - about $6 billion. Three months ago, the Hong Kong government released a consultation paper on whether Hong Kong should bid to host the 2023 Asian Games, Most in the community and in political circles are less than enthusiastic.

Title: World AIDS Day
Content description: There is in some circles the idea that AIDs and HIV are not such a big deal any more. Retroviral cocktails, often taken in large amounts, sometimes appear to reduce them to manageable chronic conditions. But it isn’t as simple as that. And to mark World AIDs Day on Wednesday, campaigners were out this week making the point that this is no time to get complacent.

Title: Part Two
Content description: Wikileaks and Liu Xiaobo

Title: Part One
Content description: Wikileaks and Liu Xiaobo

Title: Uncle Ray and CE (Full)
Content description: Uncle Ray and CE

Title: Part One
Content description:
Christmas and Casual Sex 

Can a 14-year-old rape?

Title: Christmas Eve Special - Part One
Content description:
Whether they are of a particularly religious bent or otherwise, for many Christmas is a time of goodwill, and a time to think a little more about the wishes and needs of others. That’s why tonight we’re focusing on organisations that help the less fortunate, and we will be interviewing a Santa or two later. Like most celebrations and festivals, this is a time of year when it’s good to be with others rather than sitting home alone. But even that is not so easy for some people. 

One charity organization, Direction, has been giving the disabled the opportunity to go out and socialize like the rest of us, like a trip to the airport and Christmas buffet.

For people with disabilities, isolation can worsen many of the problems they face in other areas of their life. Communicating with others plays an important role in overcoming such isolation, but for the deaf it’s very often precisely that communication that’s the greatest difficulty. "Silence" was established two years ago to promote mutual respect between the hearing impaired and those with normal hearing.

Title: Xmas Eve Special Part Two
Content description:
Not all the socially disadvantaged are necessarily grappling with physical disabilities. For some, the difficulties are economic and educational. The prospects for the economy may be looking less bleak than they were a year again. But often the last place the results of an economic upturn are seen is in the labour market.For women without high levels of education the problem is even worse. The Hong Kong Women Workers’ Association has been providing funds to help women from low-income families run a mini-store at one tertiary institution.

All three of the organizations we’ve featured so far in tonight’s show are the beneficiaries of Operation Santa Claus, co-organised by RTHK’s Radio 3 and the South China Morning Post. There are also 13 others, all worthy causes, so if you’d like to donate, you can find out how on the RTHK website or through the South China Morning Post. But we’re going to end this Christmas Eve show with two of the things that make the season most special for children: toys and Santa.

Title: End of Year Special - Part One: Looking Back
Content description:
It's the final edition of The Pulse for 2010 or the first edition for 2011, depending on whether viewers watched our first broadcast or a later repeat. So tonight, we’re looking both back and ahead.

In Part One we look back, not at the year but at the first decade of the 21st century. How have things changed? Businessman and politician Bernard Chan, activist Jackie Hung, and teacher Sam Tse give us their perspectives on events in since the year 2000.

Title: End of Year Special - Part Two: Looking Forward
Content description: Party Political Upheavals

Title: Changes to IPO Regulations
Content description: Hong Kong’s stock exchange could have a good year this year, due partly to an increase in initial public offerings from mainland Chinese companies. But perhaps in order to get more of those listings, the rules have been relaxed, and in a way that some worry could reduce faith in Hong Kong’s markets in the long run. It's now possible for their reports to be vetted by mainland accountants rather than Hong Kong ones. With us in the studio is Prof. Giles Brennand of the Business Faculty of the Chinese University of Hong Kong.

Title: Paying Last Respects
Content description: The book of condolence for former legislator Szeto Wah has been outside the Legislative Council this week.Meanwhile, throughout the week legislators have been asking for clarification on whether exiled mainland dissidents will be allowed to attend his funeral. The 1989 Beijing student activist Wang Dan has pleaded to be allowed into Hong Kong and says he would cooperate with any government conditions.

Title: Reforming Hong Kong Tour Guides?
Content description: Last year, a video showing a Hong Kong tour guide “Ah Chen” hectoring a tour group from the mainland spread widely on the internet, particularly across China itself. She was reprimanding the visitors for spending too little in shops from which her agency received a commission.It was not a good image for Hong Kong tourism. In late December, the Travel Industry Council of Hong Kong, or the TIC, introduced ten new regulatory measures to improve the standard of service for tours from the mainland. Tour guides are divided on their efficacy.

Title: Part One:
Content description:
Rip-off at "The Icon"?

Government gives land to China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs

Title: Part Two
Content description: Guide Dogs for the Blind in Hong Kong

Title: China on The World Stage - Discussion (Part 1)
Content description:
According to some commentators, President Hu Jintao’s state visit to the United States, which ended last Friday, ranks alongside Deng Xiaoping’s American tour in 1979, and Jiang Zemin’s trip in 1997, as a milestone in China’s international relations, particularly with Washington.

Mr Hu arrived in the United States bearing gifts: Beijing's approval of $45 billion in new contracts for U.S. companies to export goods to China. Relations were mostly warm, although a little more guarded on issues of human rights.

So tonight, The Pulse is discussing China’s economic, political and social clout on the world scene, as well as those pesky human rights. And with us in the studio to do it are the City University’s Professor Joseph Cheng, China commentator Willy Lam, and Jean-Pierre Cabestan of Baptist University.

Title: China on The World Stage - Discussion (Part 2)
Content description:
According to some commentators, President Hu Jintao’s state visit to the United States, which ended last Friday, ranks alongside Deng Xiaoping’s American tour in 1979, and Jiang Zemin’s trip in 1997, as a milestone in China’s international relations, particularly with Washington.

Mr Hu arrived in the United States bearing gifts: Beijing's approval of $45 billion in new contracts for U.S. companies to export goods to China. Relations were mostly warm, although a little more guarded on issues of human rights.

So tonight, The Pulse is discussing China’s economic, political and social clout on the world scene, as well as those pesky human rights. And with us in the studio to do it are the City University’s Professor Joseph Cheng, China commentator Willy Lam, and Jean-Pierre Cabestan of Baptist University.

Title: Rabbits
Content description:
Kung Hei Fat Choi, and welcome to the first edition of The Pulse for the Year of the Rabbit, or if you’re Vietnamese “The Year of the Cat”.And it’s a more festive edition than usual. Tonight we’re giving politics a bit of a rest, and focusing on more seasonal topics.

In Part One, as it's the Year of the Rabbit, we focus on rabbits themselves, not only as symbois in the Chinese zodiac and mythology, but also as increasingly popular pets in space-limited Hong Kong homes.

Title: "Fai Chun"
Content description: Also in Part One, the Lunar New Year is an auspicious festival, and to increase the chances of good fortune it’s traditional to write lucky words on red papers.These papers are called “Fai Chun”, and may include such expressions as “Wishing you safety wherever you go”, and “Good Health”. We look at their origins and history.

Title: The Tong Sing or Chinese Almanac
Content description: The new year is a time for looking back and looking forward, making those famous and often soon forgotten resolution.The wish to see into the future has always been with us. In Britain, “The Old Moore’s Almanack” has been predicting weather and making astrological observations since 1697. The Chinese Almanac or “Tong Sing” has been around even longer. It hasn’t always been available to the common people, but today it's highly popular as an advisor on auspicious dates and other matters.

Title: Mainland Money
Content description: According to a report released by CLSA this week, rich mainland Chinese are likely to be major drivers in the consumption of luxury goods, surging from 15% of the global market to 44% this year. That may be good news for Hong Kong retailers, but it’s not only the high end consumer who is having an effect on Hong Kong’s retail markets. Mainland tourists have been flocking to Hong Kong armed with more purchasing power and bigger shopping bags. For them, the city remains a luxury shopping paradise. Over the last few years it has also turned into a big grocery market. As inflation rises on the mainland more and more tourists are buying food and daily necessities here. And it's having an effect on local residents, particularly in the northern New Territories

Title: New Regulations for Tourism
Content description: This week, in the wake of reports of another disagreement between a tour guide and mainland tourists, this one physical, there were calls for a new regulatory body to oversee the tourism industry. Some worry that the compensation payment to tourists will encourage more visitors to actually encourage altercations. Others worry more about the effect on Hong Kong’s tourism industry, and ask whether it's time for a new regulatory body. With us in the studio is the Deputy Commissioner for Tourism. Miss Rosanna Law.

Title: Rainbow Warrior II in Hong Kong
Content description: The Greenpeace flagship, the Rainbow Warrior II, is currently in Hong Kong as part of its farewell tour in Asia. The ship, originally a fishing trawler, was bought 22 years ago with compensation money received by the environmental group after the French secret service bombed the first Rainbow Warrior.Given Greenpeace’s reputation for activism, the ship’s presence here does have a few people nervous.

Title: Travel Subsidy Scheme
Content description: The government is expanding the Work Incentive Transport Subsidy Scheme, already introduced in four city districts, to cover all of Hong Kong. But its own journey to doing that hasn’t been without complications. The objective of the plan is to encourage individuals to take up employment even far away from their home, but some - who were eligible before the expansion - are no long eligible. Under the revised plan the allowance is based on household income.

Title: Light Pollution
Content description: Let there be light. But preferably not all night long. We look at the problem of light pollution. For decades, due to the fact that Kai Tak airport was so close to the city, there were strict regulations covering light emitted by billboards, and stipulating that flashing and otherwise moving lights could not be used. Well, the airport’s moved, the restrictions have been lifted, and some residents are finding themselves a little more in the glare than they’d like to be,

Title: Harrassment of Property Owners
Content description: Red banners congratulating owners for selling have been hung outside old buildings in many different districts across Hong Kong, after one particular property company has acquired several units for redevelopment.Those who haven’t agreed to sell often find themselves facing a sea of trouble. Mysterious fires break out, electricity junctions get damaged rats and cockroaches appear, and excrement is left in stairways and passageways. And that's not all.

Title: The Budget
Content description:
Financial Secretary John Tsang’s Fourth Budget hasn’t exactly been received with glowing praise. He said he saw combating inflation as his main task. But while the Financial Secretary was delivering his speech various organizations outside the Legislative Council building were saying he should have been combating poverty. The public wants its money back. Or at least some of it. In the current fiscal year the government has a surplus of 71.3 billion Hong Kong dollars. The response from politicians was among the most negative for any Budget in the past decade.

With us in the studio to discuss the Budget is Professor Ho Lok-sang, economist and director of the Centre for Public Policy Studies at Lingnan University.

Title: No Jasmine Please, We're Hongkongers
Content description: People’s uprisings in the Middle East have been spreading across the region. Some are hoping, while others are worried, that they may even reach Asia. There were calls for a “Jasmine Revolution” to begin last weekend in many Chinese cities. No one knew who made those calls, authorities were on the alert, and they fizzled out. But carrying a bunch of flowers isn’t without its risks even in Hong Kong. Ask legislator Lee Cheuk-yan.

Title: Who Controls Hong Kong's Development?
Content description: Officials from Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Dongguan, Guangzhou, Zhongshan, Zhuhai and Macau have outlined a controversial series of development projects entitled “The Action Plan for the Bay Area of the Pearl River Estuary”. Its aim is, say its proponents, to improve the region’s quality of life. It could affect close to 25 million across the region.This month, Hong Kong ended its three-week public consultation this month, but it’s been so low-key you may not have noticed.The plan’s been criticized as being full of bureaucratic buzzwords, and much less full of information that will allow better comprehension. A mainland-led research team conducted the study. Hong Kong legislators were not consulted

Title: A Budget Cash Payout - But Is It Enough?
Content description: For a while it looked as if there could a constitutional crisis after a majority of political groups aired their negative reaction to this year’s Budget. However, to no-one’s great surprise, the pro-government parties have now fallen into line, so the Budget will get the required votes from legislators. That happened after the government has agreed to dish out unprecedented sums of cash to the public, but there’s still criticism over a pronounced lack of long term planning.

Title: Designer and Manufacturer Synergy
Content description: In part one we were reporting on that extra money most Hong Kong residents will be getting in their pockets as a result of the Budget. Some are already musing on how they are going to spend it. If they want to help boost the local economy they can spend it on Hong Kong-made products, but how many are as easily identifiable as say Apple, or Sony? A new initiative financed by Create Hong Kong is looking at how Hong Kong companies can boost their branding and products with the help of local designers.

Title: Children with Rare Diseases
Content description: Hong Kong’s a competitive society, and the competition starts early, even for children with no illnesses or physical disabilities to deal with. For those who suffer from rare genetic diseases it can be an even more unforgiving environment. Some of them respond with even more determination to beat the odds.

Title: Mao's Great Famine
Content description: Mao's Great Famine

Title: Cracks in the Hospital Authority
Content description: Cracks in the Hospital Authority

Title: Does Government Hill Have a Future?
Content description: Two months ago, a topping-out ceremony was held for the Tamar Development Project which includes the new Government Headquarters, the Legislative Council Complex and an open leisure space. If all goes according to plan, existing government offices on Lower Albert Road will be relocated to Tamar by the end of this year.But where does that leave Government Hill? If the administration has its way, a considerable proportion of it will be left in the hands of commercial developers.

Title: Should we ban trawling?
Content description: Should we ban trawling?

Title: Scotching the earthquake rumours
Content description: Scotching the earthquake rumours

Title: Japan Earthquake Preparedness
Content description: Japan Earthquake Preparedness

Title: The Earthquake and the Media
Content description: The Earthquake and the Media

Title: The Pulse
Content description: School Bullying

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Food from Japan

Title: The Pulse
Content description: The Let Strays Starve Campaign

Title: Power (Part One)
Content description:
The crisis at the nuclear power plant in Fukushima has sparked new debate on the ways in which we get our electricity.

This week, The Pulse devotes its whole show to the issue of the power we use. 

Hong Kong is not, generally, a city that cares about how it uses electricity. This week though, legisltaors asked the government to consider new alternatives for our future power mix. Unfortunately, we don't have that many options open to us.

Title: Power - An Antarctic Experiment
Content description:
The crisis at the nuclear power plant in Fukushima has sparked new debate on the ways in which we get our electricity.

This week, The Pulse devotes its whole show to the issue of the power we use. 

In Part Two we talk to three members of CLP's Project COOL, which sends certain staff to the Antarctic to observe the effects of global warming and provide sustainable energy for an unmanned weather station there.

Title: The Detention of Ai Weiwei
Content description: In the eyes of many, the arrest of Ai Weiwei sends a chillding message to many dissidents, and that message is: "No matter how high profile you are, we can take you any time we want".

Title: Part One - Minimum Wage and Mei Foo Sun Chuen Development
Content description:
The Minimum Wage Ordinance comes into effect at the beginning of next month, but the government has left glaring loopholes in it, and employers are not slow to take advantage. Some workers will end up earning less than they did before the regulation is introduced. 

Residents in Mei Foo Sun Chuen are furious that a site that once housed an LPG depot is going to be redeveloped as a 20-storey residential building. They say the government has misled them about the development, and changed its stance to support the developers.

Title: Resentment of mainlanders
Content description: The Budget, to no-one’s great surprise has passed, along with the $6,000 handout to Hong Kong residents. That;’s caused a little controversy, as some don’t feel recent arrivals from the mainland should be eligible. It’s just one part of an ongoing resentment of mainlanders for straining local resources, felt by some in Hong Kong.

Title: Are Hong Kong's Politics Too Confrontational?
Content description: Hong Kong’s activists are getting more active. And, in some cases, more confrontational. Officials are arguing that such aggressive tactics are counter-productive and anti-social, but others argue that if you thwart democratic reform, this is what you get. Well with us in the studio are Michael deGolyer of the Hong Kong Transition Project and Avery Ng of the League of Social Democrats.

Title: Social Enterprises
Content description: Some feel that government should do everything it can to take care of society’s disadvantaged. Others, in a strategy supported by social conservatives as well as those of a more community-oriented bent, feel that social enterprises are often better equipped to fulfil that need.

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Part One

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Part Two

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Ashes to Ashes

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Keeping Our Illegal Structures

Title: The Pulse
Content description: Tax on Tobacco

Title: Cross Harbour Tunnel Blues
Content description: You can get from Kowloon to Hong Kong island in less than five minutes by MTR, less than 15 by the Star Ferry, and – in some rush hours – more than 45 minutes by the Hung Hom cross harbour tunnel. Still, many drivers prefer to wait, given that the tolls for the other tunnels are so much higher. Legislator Chan Kam-lam pointed out in the Legislative Council this week that part of that congestion is caused by the Autotoll payment system.

Title: Consumers International
Content description: This week, representatives of consumers, and representatives from industries and governments, are in Hong Kong to discuss solutions that will make a difference. Delegates from over 60 countries have been at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre for the 19th Consumers International World Congress, organised by Consumers International and the Hong Kong Consumer Council. The main topic? Empowering tomorrow’s consumers.Increasingly those consumers are concerned about issues such as climate change, faltering economies, sustainable consumption, health and food safety, and how new technologies are affecting consumer rights. Worldwide, middle-class consumers are increasingly vocal, using their clout to affect global consumption and production.

Title: What's the Policy Unit For?
Content description: Former Hong Kong Governor David Wilson set up the Central Policy Unit as a government think tank in 1989. His successor Chris Patten also relied on it for accurate feedback from the community. It has continued to function since 1997, although some have vocally questioned how much the government relies on it, given how often government decisions seem at odds with public opinion.This week in Legco’s question time, the Civic Party’s Alan Leong asked the government about media reports of a recent survey commissioned by the Central Policy Unit. According to those reports, questions in the survey, conducted by the Chinese University, included whether it was necessary for the Financial Secretary to resign and whether the SAR government was facing a governance crisis. Government officials refused to disclose directly whether they had conducted such a survey. Legislators also wanted to know what role the Central Policy Unit currently plays in the administration.

Title: Moral and National Education (Part Two)
Content description:
"Give me the child until he is seven, and I will give you the man," runs a quote attributed to St. Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Jesuit order.

Getting the right stuff into eager young minds as early as possible is clearly important to some.

The Hong Kong government now wants some of that “right stuff” to be part of what it likes to call the “Moral and National Education” subject for primary and secondary students. 

The subject has yet to be introduced, but it is the topic of The Pulse for tonight.

With us in the studio are Cheung Kwok-wah of the Education Bureau, and Lee Chack-fan who is chairman of an ad-hoc committee set up to oversee the implementation of the classes.And we also have with us Pauline Chow of the Women Teachers’ Organisation, and Ip Kin-yuen of the Professional Teachers’ Union

Title: Moral and National Education (Part One)
Content description:
"Give me the child until he is seven, and I will give you the man," runs a quote attributed to St. Ignatius of Loyola, the founder of the Jesuit order.

Getting the right stuff into eager young minds as early as possible is clearly important to some.

The Hong Kong government now wants some of that “right stuff” to be part of what it likes to call the “Moral and National Education” subject for primary and secondary students. 

The subject has yet to be introduced, but it is the topic of The Pulse for tonight.

With us in the studio are Cheung Kwok-wah of the Education Bureau, and Lee Chack-fan who is chairman of an ad-hoc committee set up to oversee the implementation of the classes. And we also have with us Pauline Chow of the Women Teachers’ Organisation, and Ip Kin-yuen of the Professional Teachers’ Unio

Title: No More Byelections
Content description: Under proposed new by-election rules, if the legislator you voted for, at least in a geographical constituency, resigns, falls ill or dies, he or she is likely to be replaced by someone who stands for exactly the opposite of what you voted for. It’s a novel approach to democracy, not practised – as far as we known anywhere else in the world - but the government, and Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam, believe it’s entirely appropriate for Hong Kong.

Title: Stemming the Plastic Bag Flood
Content description:
We begin with the ubiquitous plastic bag. Since legislation was introduced in 2009, supermarkets at least have not been giving them away with such abandon as they used to. But now the government is planning to extend the reach of the levy. The latest government proposal will extend the plastic shopping bag levy to all 60,000 retail stores in the city.If it’s passed, retailers will collect 50 cents for each plastic bag shoppers take as from 2013. But how successful has the levy been?

With us in the studio is Albert Lam, the Deputy Director of the Environmental Protection Department.

Title: Einstein in Hong Kong
Content description: According to at least one American pastor, now widely believed to have been mistaken, the end of the world was coming the day after our broadcast, or at least the beginning of the end. Well, until it actually does come, at least before the end of August, you have a brief chance to rush to the Museum of Science for an exhibition about the life and work of the 20th century physicist who perhaps has done more than any other in explaining to us some of the mysteries of our world, and indeed our universe. Albert Einstein.

Title: Cerntenary of the Xinhai Revolution
Content description: The 1911 Xinhai or Chinese Revolution began with the Wuchang Uprising on October 10th of that year, and resulted in the abdication of Emperor Puyi on February 12, the following year. It was largely motivated by anger at government corruption, frustration with foreign encroachment in China, and resentment of a Manchu dominated ruling class. It’s widely seen as the first step towards a unified China, so why does it still stir up so much political disagreement in Hong Kong? And just what is being celebrated?

Title: Environmental Impact Assessments - A Stacked Deck?
Content description:
Do concerns about the environment stand in the way of progress? The Chief Executive seems to think so, judging from his comments in the Legislative Council last week. Or at least, he believes that political parties are using environmental concerns for political ends.

With us in the studio are Betty Ho who is a current member of the Environmental Impact Assessment Committee, and a former member of the same committee Ho Kin-chung.

Title: Part Two
Content description:
Article 23 Resurfaces

Lately, with the current Chief Executive nearing the end of his term, people have been raising the question of whether the next CE should act to introduce national security legislation under Article 23 of the Basic Law.This week National People's Congress delegate Peter Wong warned that various organisations may have already committed subversion with comments that challenge Beijing's authority. But is Hong Kong any more willing to accept Article 23 legislation than it was in 2003, when half a million people marched against it? Alan Hoo and Alan Leong came to The Pulse studio to discuss this with Danny Gittings, a barrister and former journalist who now teaches on Hong Kong’s constitutional law.

Title: Part One
Content description:
Illegal Structures

In May, New Territories villagers were asking the government to let them keep illegal structures they’ve added to their houses over the years. The government denied it had been lax over such structures.But in the wake of that, sightings of illegal structures have been busting out all over, many of them on the properties of government officials. 

Relocating Government Offices

Hopefully, THEY don’t have illegal additions, but many government offices sit on prime land. The administration has been saying it plans to move them into less central areas to make more room for commercial business. But when?

Title: Part Two
Content description:
Do We Need a Third Runway?

Does Hong Kong airport need a new runway? The Airport Authority is currently holding a public consultaiton on options for expansion in the future. And the government highly favours the construction of a new railway, at considerable expense, and some environmental cost.

Also, Commemmorating June 4th.

Title: Part One
Content description:
Influence Peddling in Government?

This week, legislators examined the question of whether undue influence was exerted in the awarding of one IT contract. Jeremy Godfrey, who has resigned from the Civil Service, says he was told the contract had to be awarded to a iProA, a DAB linked company, and that the advice came from high up the chain of command. 

CFA Asks for Interpretation of Basic Law

The Court of Final Appeal consults Beijing on the question of absolute state immunity for state-owned enterprises. Micheal Davis of the Chinese University of Hong Kong explains exactly what this may mean.

Title: Part Two (a)
Content description:
Is China Eavesdropping on Drivers?

If you regularly cross the border into mainland China and have a dual license plate, you’ll have been given a device to place in your vehicle. They supposedly speed cross-border processing. But some local lorry drivers, not to mention smugglers, have begun to get suspicious. Do they relay more than your vehicle statistics?

Title: Part Two (b)
Content description:
Nuclear Power Forum

Last Friday, as we prepared to go to air, local think tank Civic Exchange held a public forum on nuclear power. And it’s a topic that even splits Green groups, with some arguing that nuclear power is the least environmentally damaging option; others saying that misses the point, which is that we should just get used to using less energy anyway.

Title: Part One
Content description:
Labour Unrest in Guangzhou

Simmering tensions in labour relations in the mainland are sometimes exacerbated by the tough conditions faced by migrant workers. Now and again, these tensions bubble over into open confrontation, as they did last weekend. The unrest was triggered when a pregnant migrant woman from Sichuan province was asked to remove her hawker’s stall by village security officers on Friday night. Workers accused the villages’ security officers of pushing the pregnant woman to the ground. Those accusations led to a violent conflict between workers and security officers. Hundreds of people, mainly workers from Sichuan workers, flocked to the area. Some hurled bricks and bottles at municipality officers.

Geoffrey Crothall of the China Labour Bulletin talks to us about labour tensions in the mainland.

Title: Resuming the Home Ownership Scheme
Content description: The discussion on resuming the Home Ownership Scheme took on new impetus when the visiting Director of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office Wang Guangya reminded the Hong Kong government that it needed to tackle housing problems. The scheme, initiated in 1978, it provided a chance for more Hong Kong residents to own an apartment at an affordable price. But when the property market dropped in 2002, the government shelved the plan.

Title: Sub-divided apartments
Content description: A fire last week in a subdivided apartment space suggested that apart from being just inconvenient, a very pricy property market can be fatal. This isn’t a new problem. On the first of June, legislators had already asked the government whether it had a full picture of the situation regarding sub-divided units. Now the government's playing catch-up.

Title: Joining the PLA
Content description: In a newspaper interview published on June 7th, PLA Chief of General Staff Chen Bingde said, for the first time, that Hong Kong people would be welcome to join the army in future. But many in Hong Kong still view the military force with considerable ambivalence.

Title: Legislators Resign From By-Election Committee
Content description: On Wednesday, pan-democratic lawmakers resigned en masse from a Legco committee examining the government’s proposal to scrap by-elections in geographical constituencies and the five new district council constituency seats.With us in the studio is one of the twelve democrats who resigned, Cyd Ho.

Title: Getting Tough on Democracy?
Content description: First this week, the July 1st March, and this year there’s been much concern about whether the government is cracking down on the event itself more than in the past.

Title: Why are they marching? (1)
Content description: In 2003 it was easy enough to se what the central issue was in the march, but what about this year? With us in the studio are three of this year’s march participants and organisers James Hon of the Professional Teachers’ Union, Sze Lai-shan of SOCO, and the LSD’s Avery Ng

Title: Why are they Marching? (2)
Content description: Well, in 2003 it was easy enough to se what the central issue was in the march, but what about this year? With us in the studio are three of this year’s march participants and organisers James Hon of the Professional Teachers’ Union, Sze Lai-shan of SOCO, and the LSD’s Avery Ng

Title: So you want to be a funeral director?
Content description: There are two professions they say society will always need. Doctors and undertakers. Any other connections between the two are almost entirely coincidental. The funeral industry is inevitably interacting with its customers at a time that’s very difficult for them. And it’s dealing with a subject many of us like to spend most of our lives pretending doesn’t exist. Still some young people do want to get into the trade, and now classes are springing up to help them.

Title: Where does the Heung Yee Kuk get its power?
Content description: The recent confrontation between tthe Heung Yee Kuk and the administration over the issue of illegal structures on village houses, highlights once again the political clout of the rural organisation. But what are the historical origins of that political clout? Almost every Hong Kong government has approached the Kuk with kid gloves.

Title: By-election climbdown
Content description: It's climbdown after climbdown. The government's plan to scrap by-elections in the event of the resignation of geographically-elected lawmakers resigning or dying mid-term met with controversy from the outset. The government says it prevents abuse of the system. The democrats say it disenfranchises the population. The government said it wouldn't budge. Then it changed its proposal, saying this was the final position. Now it's withdrawn even the revised plan from debate in Legco because it doesn't have enough votes to pass it, and is finally having a pulblic consultation.

Title: ESF Subsidies Under Threat
Content description: The ESF, or English Schools Foundation currently operates nine primary schools, five secondary schools and one special school in Hong Kong. It was established in 1967 under the English Schools Foundation Ordinance. Unlike other international schools, the ESF has been receiving subvention from the Hong Kong Government. But that is under threat.

Title: Developing Nam Sang Wai Wetlands
Content description: Thanks to the fact that vast swathes of Hong Kong’s green areas are on hills it’s difficult to build on, Hong Kong has a reasonable acreage of natural space. But some of the most important areas are under constant threat from developers. And one is the wetlands at Nam Sang Wai.

Title: Voluntary Medical Insurance
Content description: Many people seem to be getting sick at the moment. The weather isn’t helping. Hopefully it’s mainly minor illnesses. For more serious problems the government is proposing to set up a private medical scheme by 2015. It plans to set aside $50 billion to subsidise medical insurance plans. Some worry that rather than taking care of the poor, the disadvantaged and high-risk patients much of the money will end up in the pockets of private insurers and medical services.

Title: Medical Insurance - Discussion
Content description: With us in the studio to discuss the medical insurance issue are Dr Tse Hung-hing of the Health & Medical Development Advisory Committee and Dr George Cautherley of the Health Care Policy Forum.

Title: Embryo Mix-Up
Content description: If you go to most medical clinics or hospitals you expect many procedures to be handled by qualified individuals. Recently though, an incident at one of Hong Kong’s most respected fertility clinics became international news, and highlighted that when it comes to dealing with human embryos no specific qualifications may be required.

Title: Goodbye Legco Building
Content description: Hong Kong’s former Supreme Court Building has been home to the Legislative Council since 1985. It’s seen a lot of changes as the Legislative Council has gone from a body that essentially rubberstamped administration decisions to a body in which administration decisions still go ahead - thanks to its composition - but with a bit more discussion and controversy along the way. This week the final Legco meeting was held in the building, which will soon revert to becoming the home of the court of Final Appeal.

Title: Right of Abode for Domestic Helpers
Content description: In Hong Kong, you are, in the normal, run of things, eligible to apply for Permanent Resident status. Job description usually doesn’t matter … unless you have been working as a domestic helper. In that case, you can have been here for twenty years or thirty years and still not be eligible. Now some are arguing that under the provisions of the Basic Law this amounts to job discrimination.

Title: Chief Executive Race
Content description:
We begin our new series of The Pulse by looking at the Chief Executive race. So far, there are three main contenders, although last minute upsets still can’t be ruled out. If the process were a popular election, media allegations about the private life of Henry Tang this week might well have an effect on the results. But, as many commentators have pointed out, what really counts is the wind from the North. Many of the 1,200 members of the Election Committee will mostly be trying to gauge Beijing’s preferences. Leung Chun-ying is relatively unpopular with Hong Kong’s business elite, and many are wary of his longtime Beijing connections. He’s been campaigning to win public support for as long as two years.The third candidate, Albert Ho, representing the pan-Democrats, knows he doesn't stand a chance, but does feel his participation may make the other contenders more accountable.

Albert Ho is in our studio with political commentator James Sung.

Title: Right of Abode for Domestic Helpers
Content description: Last week, Hong Kong's High Court ruled that a domestic helper from the Philippines should be allowed to apply for Right of Abode The case was brought by Evangeline Banao Vallejos, who has lived here since 1986. Hong Kong's Secretary for Security, Ambrose Lee has said that the government will not process or approve right-of-abode applications for domestic workers while it appeals the ruling. Meanwhile, some political groups have made their opposition very clear.

Title: Too Poor for a Healthy Diet
