（歌曲：最卑微的願望　　主唱：張敬軒）

全球抗疫WHO CARES
武漢肺炎自去年年底初現，中國監控不足換來全球大爆發，世衛總幹事譚德塞卻高舉支持中國的旗幟，多次讚揚中國在疫情上方方面面都做得好。可是全球確診人數不斷上升，各國封關、撤僑，嚴防病毒入境。面對嚴竣疫情，世衛有發揮到應有的角色嗎？
（歌曲：神奇女俠的退休生活　　主唱：謝安琪）

Title: 第3集—憑著愛
Content description:
憑著愛
疫情嚴重，太后憑著愛親自上街派發口罩，勞心勞力，就是不明白為何民意支持度仍跌至單位數字，即100個人裏只有9個人支持太后，要在10個人裏找到一個支持她的人，也沒有…假民調！一定是被誤導的主流意見！

撐派糖　保民望？
財爺發表新一份財政預算案，提出多項寬免措施，並使出全民派錢招數！財爺的「元氣彈」能否幫助經濟恢復元氣？能否平息民怨、挽救政府民望？
（歌曲：龍珠　　主唱：張崇基張崇德）

物有所值？
財政司司長陳茂波表示，上年反修例示威期間，警隊「相當辛苦」，因此，發放津貼、增加資源購買裝備實屬「應該、合理」，是物有所值！
（歌曲：粒糖有毒　　主唱：王菀之）

愛迫封關
政府一直不願對內地全面封關，聲稱傷感情、不應助長歧視、針對式排斥某部分人！但因應南韓疫情急速惡化，港府今個星期迅速向南韓封關。今次「果斷地」話封就封，又有否歧視？
（歌曲：斷絕來往　　主唱：陳柏宇）

罪與罰
南韓的新型肺炎確診個案超過2000宗，眾多患者都是源自新天地教會。疫情不斷，教徒堅持讀經聚會，引來病毒反覆傳播，究竟是信者的罪、神的懲罰、還是政府的錯？
（歌曲：罪與罰　　主唱：鄭秀文(feat.24Herbs)

Title: 第4集—好心分手
Content description:
好心分手
好心一早放開我，成日投訴太坎坷~~~太后心情大好，約同包豪星唱卡拉ＯＫ，太后的歌喉…要給一隻手指公啦！

一切如常？
沉寂了一段時間，馬會投注站重開，公務員自備口罩復工去；特首落區打打氣，高官齊齊捐薪一個月，議員言之鑿鑿指蒸口罩有效，凡此種種，市民在疫情迫降下，生活是否一切如常？
（歌曲：子華說　　主唱：古巨基featuring黃子華）

咱們終于回家！
多得中央關心、湖北省政府人力和物力上配合，特區政府終於可對滯留湖北港人說：「走，咱們回家！」湖北地區封城超過一個月，政府本周共安排四班包機，接載469名滯留港人回家！但仍有3000多名港人滯留當地，回家無期…
（歌曲：城記　　主唱：Rubberband）

My TV SUFFER 
《擔心字典》再度登場；蒸口罩不是嘥功夫，元秋的口罩重用法﹗

一哥式回應
警務處處長鄧炳強現身，一口氣回應了多個市民關心的問題，包括831事件半周年的衝突、警員向記者噴胡椒噴霧、就21宗案件訓斥警員及「學成龍做警察」的言論…一哥的回應市民收貨嗎？
（歌曲：幽默感　　主唱：何韻詩）

超級對手
俗稱「超級星期二」的美國民主黨總統初選大勢已定，前副總統拜登惡鬥參議員桑德斯，前者勝出10個州的初選，起死回生。如若拜登最終代表民主黨對戰特朗普，美國選民又是否會接受這名溫和派代表，還是繼續支持習主席的好朋友呢？
（歌曲：天敵　　主唱：衛蘭）

Title: 第5集—大流行
Content description:
全球大流行
「生命就好像a box of口罩，你永遠不知道抽到厚的還是薄的。」
疫症全球大流行，連國際影星湯漢斯也確診了，但只要哪人一天未確診，太后仍然會很放心地不需戴口罩去體察民情，哪人是…

內外抗疫
繼打邊爐家族、佛堂群組及鑽石公主號後，埃及旅行團成另一個本港確診個案較多的群體。現時疫情被列為全球大流行，政府繼續採取圍堵策略，並呼籲港人如非必要不要外遊。市民可以待在家裏勤洗手，那麼依靠遊客的旅行社如何是好？
（歌曲：自由行　　主唱：楊千嬅）

無人完美
過去的星期六，將軍澳和大埔再次出現警民衝突，有記者被推倒、市民被要求逐一向警察道歉，特首林鄭月娥叫市民要包容好大壓力的警方，剛調任葵青警區指揮官的謝振中則在區議會會議上表明並沒有所謂「警民衝突」，是有人犯法，警察執法。
（歌曲：無人完美　　主唱：鄭欣宜）

條數點計？
接到999緊急來電，警方要多久才到場？警方稱去年新界區有近九成八的緊急求助，都可以在15分鐘內回應，數字並沒有計算去年721元朗事件中接獲的二萬多個報案電話…不，是有計算的，計算了接通的1100個電話，其餘的？明顯是別有用心的人有心搞事…警方的計算方程式的確是神奇、頂級、超卓！
（歌曲：正邪說　　主唱： Pandora樂隊）

大流行
疫情蔓延至全球六大洲、超過100個國家後，世衛終於！終於！終於宣佈—新型冠狀病毒列為全球大流行！中國疫情開始緩和，但意大利等歐美國家確診數字急增，矛頭直指世衛反應太慢、中國隱瞞疫情，令各國輕視疫情以致未能及時防疫。
（歌曲：重口味　　主唱：陳奕迅）

Title: 第6集—佛系抗疫
Content description:
佛系抗疫
「南無南無，乜都唔駛做，坐定定喺度。」西天已經全封關了，唐僧不能去西天取經，唯有佛系地坐著不動。太后似乎對這種佛系方法很有興趣，派小豪子打聽一下，是否有值得參考的地方。

第二波
本港新型肺炎確診數字持續上升，隨著大批海外留學生回港，第二波疫情隨時殺到！香港向全球國家和地區發出紅色旅遊警示，而抵港人士需要接受強制家居檢疫，措施能否有效應對可能出現的大爆發？
（歌曲：S.O.S.　　主唱：容祖兒）

蠢蠢欲動
新一屆立法會選舉將於九月舉行，選管會建議長者可優先投票，但強調並非鼓勵「打尖」。另外，新民黨容海恩退出黨內初選，又揚言「自己肯定好過李梓敬」。立法會議員何君堯亦頻頻落區，積極推動廿三條立法，大家正蠢蠢欲動…
（歌曲：16號愛人　　主唱:容祖兒）

【My TV SUFFER】
「咪出街by小學雞」—你咪出街～咪周圍FLY～
《擔心字典》—今次講「胃」字！

忘記或記
監警會網上公開會議上，警方指，示威者在反修例事件中越來越暴力，是因為他們的憤怒和憤恨，令他們脫離人性…於是，大半年來發生過的畫面，又再呈現，香港人可以做的，或者只有「忘記」或「記」這兩個選項。
（歌曲：忘記和記　　主唱：麥浚龍、黎明）

歐洲封關
歐盟宣佈歐洲封關三十天！世衛宣佈歐洲為病毒的大流行中心，歐洲各國領袖呼籲國民嚴陣以待。歐洲超過十萬宗確診個案，是世衛通報緩慢，還是歐洲反應遲鈍？剛脱歐的英國本來採用「佛系」抗疫法，但首相約翰遜日前卻突然積極，宣佈無限期停課，會否已經太遲？
（歌曲：廢城故事　　主唱：梁漢文）

Title: 第7集—禁酒令
Content description:
禁酒令
太后說，飲醉少少很容易會有親密行為，但包豪星喝到酩酊大醉，結果甚麼事都沒發生過，正打算跟太后對質，太后反問，現在飲酒重要還是人命重要！

停一停
政府於上周六推出多項針對疫情的措施，包括延遲中學文憑試及關閉各類政府康樂設施。特首於本周一再建議「禁酒令」，但卻遭到多名行會成員反對。事隔數天，特首表示聽到社會的意見，會擱置「禁酒令」，改為一系列針對聚會及餐飲業的措施。市民是時候停一停聚會，忍一忍留家。
（歌曲：今夜很寧靜　　主唱：陳慧琳）

封城14天
拖拉兩個月至今，特首終於按照其「一直迅速應變疫情的方針」，宣佈封城14天。由本周三凌晨起禁止非港人入境，但從內地、台灣及澳門入境人士，過去兩周未到過海外，則可入境作強制檢疫。本地確診個案不斷增加，政府再派包機接載滯留湖北港人返港，疫情仍然嚴峻…
（歌曲：南瓜車　　主唱：薛凱琪）

八個月
721事件過去八個月，警方多次回應時都轉移視線，避談白衣人責任。上周六，元朗再次有人堵路，這一次，警方「警力充足」維持治安，並以胡椒噴霧「軀散」在場記者…
（歌曲：傷追人　　主唱：古巨基）

不安倍增？
全球疫情大爆發，原定七月舉行的2020東京奧運亦成為史上首次延期的奧運會。多年的期望，換成今天的失望！這個「被詛咒」的奧運會明年能否順利舉行，仍是未知之數...
（歌曲：多少年　　主唱：JW）

Title: 第8集—禁聚令
Content description:
禁聚令
因為美容院出現感染個案，太后唯有留在家中做facial，包豪星要親自上門，問候太后隻手是否安好…

保持距離
政府上周推出抗疫新措施，關閉6類場所14天，但卡拉OK場所卻不需停業。直至本周出現卡拉OK感染群組，政府才宣佈關閉卡拉OK、麻雀館及夜總會等場所，但卻不包括有確診個案的美容院，政府形容做法是順應疫情的發展迅速應變。
（歌曲：逃避你　　主唱：容祖兒）

執法
禁聚令生效，警方在831事件7個月，按禁令截查了75人；在食肆外等外賣，警方要求４人一組分開站好；另外，嚴謹遵守1.5米的社交距離，要求互不相識的食客搭枱。警隊嚴正執法，同心抗疫！
（歌曲：暴風一族　　主唱：張國榮）

My TV SUFFER
「四個就夠晒數」—四個就夠晒數，周圍touch is dangerous!
《擔心字典》—禁令之下，今次講「禁」字！

祝君健康
本港疫情嚴峻，每日新增確診個案維持雙位數字，更有多宗感染源頭不明個案…加上一線負壓病房接近飽和，專家擔心疫情失控！醫護一再呼籲市民減少不必要社交，減輕醫護壓力。
（歌曲：身體健康　　主唱：張衛健）

疫情現代化
新型肺炎持續肆虐全球，世衛及多國均呼籲人們宅在家中。宅在家中不但可以直播上課、遙距健身，還可以振興「宅經濟」！疫情令人類的生活模式改變，人工智能和大數據在全球抗疫中擔當重要角色，但疫情過後，科技會繼續協助人類，還是反監察人類？
（歌曲：第五個現代化　　主唱：陳奕迅）

Title: 第9集—抗疫減人工
Content description:
抗疫減人工
太后喊冤…抗爭運動時，大家都怪責太后不按機制辦事；現在太后跟機制加人工，大家又叫她不要跟機制﹗好亂啊…

抗疫齊鼓掌
特首及司局長宣佈將於未來一年減薪一成，以示與市民共渡時艱，亦推出千億元抗疫紓緩措施，包括800億補貼僱主支付員工薪金。政府大灑金錢保就業，能否同時保民望、贏掌聲？
（歌曲：最佳努力獎　　主唱：陳柏宇）

專家意見
疫情之始，政府成立專家小組為抗疫提供意見，特首林鄭月娥強調依照專家意見推抗疫政策。港大微生物學系講座教授袁國勇為專家團隊其中一員，由2003年沙士到今天一直與港人同在。作為專家，為疫情發聲，專家給的意見，你有在聽嗎？
（歌曲：醫生的悲哀　　主唱：陳柏宇）

千呼萬喚
警務處處長鄧炳強首次出席立法會會議，接受議員質詢。「不偏不倚」四個字，彷彿成為了鄧炳強的口頭禪！會上，多名議員關注警方執法問題，鄧炳強指警方一向是不偏不倚，每宗案件都是一絲不苟深入調查。
（歌曲：一切正常　　主唱：吳浩康）

口罩爭奪戰
全球疫情肆虐，各國醫療物資短缺，更出現爭口罩情況！法國及德國相繼指責美國「截劫」其訂購的口罩，批評美國如「現代海盜」。同時，中國積極出售及捐贈口罩等物資予各國，大打口罩外交。
（歌曲：口罩　　主唱：Mr.）

Title: 第10集—鐵證如山
Content description:
政治攬炒
城中那位狀師罪行滔天、鐵證如山，太后要求包豪星將他治罪。鐵證如山⋯⋯是指哪一座山呢？

鐵證如山
中聯辦及港澳辦聯手譴責公民黨立法會議員郭榮鏗，拖延立法會內會正副主席選舉，是「政治攬炒」，涉嫌公職人員行為失當。特首林鄭月娥認為，兩辦就香港事務發聲是理所當然，不存在干預。面對各方指控，郭榮鏗表示：「想恐嚇我的話，慳啲！」
（歌曲：大條道理　　主唱：小肥）

國家安全
「全民國家安全教育日」，今年已經是第五年舉辦，多位重量級嘉賓在線上致辭，申明國家安全，人人有責。國家安全，不是說了算，要做就需要立法…
（歌曲：愛的教育　　主唱：梅艷芳）

My TV SUFFER
健康玩呈獻—2020 Sumhui網上演唱會
《擔心字典》—同大家傾下偈，今次講個「談」字。

唔好鬆懈住！
近日疫情有緩和跡象，確診數字回落至單位數字，假日有不少市民外出，但張竹君醫生提提大家，不要掉以輕心。而疫情的影響亦逐漸浮現，企業面臨倒閉、打工仔面臨失業，第二輪防疫抗疫基金能否解燃眉之急？
（歌曲：俾啲掌聲你自己　　主唱：林海峰　蔡一智）

世衛結果
延誤分享疫情資訊、無及時提供防疫政策、遲遲未宣佈疫症大流行、過份偏袒中國……
世衛在新冠肺炎疫情上的處理手法，終令美國發火了！美國總統特朗普宣佈暫停對世衛的資助，表面是為了懲罰世衛失職，但實際更有其他考量……
（歌曲：你沒有好結果　　主唱：李蕙敏）

Title: 第11集—大換班
Content description:
為官之道
今時今日甚麼是「為官之道」？曾經見過Steve Jobs的局長都丟了Job，小豪子還是快快把太后的肖像放在書桌上，可能更有助仕途。

大換班
特區政府問責團隊大換班，五位新任局長，位位都獨具魅力、履歷出眾。特首林鄭月娥就強調，自上任以來，一直用人唯才，希望新上任的官員能帶領香港早日走出困局。
（歌曲：我們很帥　　主唱：ERROR）

監督權
究竟港澳辦和中聯辦是或不是基本法第22條所指的「中央各部門在特區設立的機構」?政府近日推翻多年前的說法，指兩辦不是第22條所指的中央各部門，對港的言論不是干預，而是有發言權、有監督權。泛民批評兩辦僭建監督權，一國兩制蕩然無存。
（歌曲：愛到不能　　主唱：盧巧音）

逐個捉
特首林鄭月娥曾說，香港回歸後遊行次數之多，足證香港自由之充份。言猶在耳，警方於4月18日上門拘捕15名民主派人士，控罪涉及去年反送中運動三場遊行。以後，還會有人敢上街嗎？
（歌曲：動物凶猛　　主唱：RubberBand）


疫轉勝
全球疫情仍然嚴峻，南韓不但穩住疫情，還來個國會選舉執政黨大勝，無疑是個「疫」轉勝！文在寅政府不但勝出國會選舉，還是首次有執政黨佔國會五分之三議席。同時北韓領袖金正恩傳出病重，南北局勢將會如何？文在寅政府會否再面對挑戰？
(歌曲：硬仗　　主唱：側田）

Title: 第12集—五一勞動節特別版
Content description:
【點。知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
今集歌手Serrini點唱《Don’t Text Him》，在疫情下大家都留在家中，「用最安好的距離，未會牽手的距離」，保持社交距離…

大帥與徐副官：欲鬧不能
真人處境節目《欲罷不能》近期大熱，大帥與徐副官也很想參加，嬴取獎金！於是他倆參加了…《欲鬧不能》，結果如何呢？

死心不息
疫情肆虐多月，限聚令繼續生效，多區商場連日出現「和你唱」，警方以市民因共同目的聚集，有違限聚令而進行驅散，聲稱這是為抗疫，跟集會自由並沒關係。
（歌曲：夜行　　主唱：林聰(feat. Hocc)）

包豪星與有為：高尚情操
包豪星沒精打采奄奄一息的，原因是一直想不通，一個人拿著兩把刀上街，為何是完全沒想過用刀傷人呢？高尚情操又是如何養成的？

My TV SUFFER
—「食唔落」—媽媽教煮「礦翼欖菜炒飯」，欖炒飯配上「中聯辦乾乳」，色香味俱全！
—《擔心字典》同你講個「還」字﹗

【頭條劇場】風雨下的基本法22條
電視節目《獅子山下》紀錄時代的面貌，1992年播放題為《風風雨雨》的一集，以紅球國總司令干預新聞節目為主題，似乎在預視著香港面對的風風雨雨。時至今日，立法會內委會面對「兩辦」的譴責，有人認為是對香港事務的關心，有人則認為是干預，雙方能否相聚於獅子山下，「拋開區分求共對」？

太后與小豪子：視像會議
疫情持續，為保持社交距離，太后跟小豪子試行視像對話，最重要鏡頭要夠闊，拍到太后舉手的情況！

未來現在學
開會ZOOM、上堂ZOOM、連做運動都用ZOOM！全球疫情爆發令人類反思未來發展，教學模式也轉向學生主導，由下而上的學習模式。但有些地方就依然主張政府話事，繼續所謂的教育改革。由上而下的管制，是否與全球趨勢背道而馳呢？
講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第13集—再出發
Content description:
太后與小豪子：銅芯
幾經辛苦，太后終於採購到口罩了，更加是以友情價購得高科技銅芯口罩，真擔心廠家要做蝕本生意啊！

【點。知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
香港再出發，出發去哪？今集樂隊ToNick點唱《不停站》，想和你講：疫境下好好養傷、休息，檢討過後繼續是其是、非其非，帶著道理和良知，重新出發。

太后與小豪子：再出發
各位團友，可以再出發了！
有經驗豐富的專業領隊，加上很多愛國商人自動自覺參加，膳食安排絕對放心，太后與小豪子，出發啦！

小李出招
面對立法會內務委員會選主席的僵局，小李終於忍不住要出招了！星期五的內會特別會議上，小李早著先機，率先登上主席台「霸位」，民主派議員縱然使出渾身解數，最後也被驅逐離場！
（歌曲：小李飛刀　　主唱：羅文）

【頭條劇場】小題大做？
1978年《獅子山下》題為《橋》的一集，居民佔領馬路抗議木橋被拆去，記者調查事件並為居民爭取合理待遇。近日有報章揭露警務處助理處長陶輝涉嫌違規居住牌照屋，促使地政總署人員上門調查，可見記者調查報道的重要性。

大帥與包豪星：視若無睹
包豪星又有事想請教大帥，但大帥只見包豪星在扮鳥飛，到底想說甚麼呢…？

未來現在學
美國上月暫停資助世衛後，國際間有聲音要另組類似世衛的組織，令人反思國際組織未來將如何定位。一個稱職的國際組織，究竟是要保護國家的整體利益、還是維護人類世界的基本權利為依歸？政治、金錢、人命，哪樣才是缺一不可？
講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第14集—無掩雞籠
Content description:
太后與小豪子：無掩雞籠
太后又收到一個包裹，內裡會否是炸彈…不用擔心，太后生日，有很多人到商場唱歌為太后慶祝，證明大家是多愛太后呢！

【點・知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
香港面對各種衝擊，這座城是否變了樣？歌手傅珮嘉點唱歌曲《傾城》，唱出對香港過往美好的思念，道出經營餐廳的困難，她亦勉勵香港人，在逆境中要有打不死的精神。

大帥與小豪子：監差會
萬眾期待，監差會的報告終於出台，厚達千多頁，份量十足，主席定幫果然一定幫到手！

記者朋友？
母親節有網民發起多區「和你唱」，入夜後記者被警方包圍截查、多次噴胡椒噴劑。警方指傳媒當天經歷「唔理想」，又稱呼傳媒為「記者朋友」，特首林鄭月娥呼籲雙方開心見誠坐低傾，至於監警會審視警方報告，特首形容是「極有份量的報告」。
（歌曲：側面　　主唱：張國榮）

【MY TV SUFFER】
「Lazy拉人」近日得閒四圍行，今集隆重登場﹗《擔心字典》同你講個「打」字，好驚驚呀！

【頭條劇場】未來主人翁？
1978年《小時候》題為《未來主人翁》的一集，志文叔叔為家其和小敏計劃了一個別開生面的旅程，希望這班未來主人翁長大後，擁有多一點美麗的回憶。
最近在限聚令實施下，香港人就過了一個難忘的母親節；另邊廂，特區政府準備「處理」通識科、 DSE歷史必答題被要求取消，我們的未來主人翁，面對怎樣的未來？

太后與包豪星：集體回憶
眼看他起高樓，眼看他宴賓客，眼看他樓塌了，海洋公園充滿集體回憶，難道真的忍心讓它執笠，變成一塊空地？

未來現在學
沒有獨立調查委員會，但Facebook有監察委員會。不久前，Facebook宣佈成立監察委員會以處理投訴或假新聞等，但不同國家對虛擬世界及網絡言論的態度不同，究竟未來的網絡國度，是屬於公司，還是國家所有？

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第15集—曼德拉
Content description:
太后與小豪子：曼德拉
「摧毀教育等於摧毀一個國家。」是誰的金句不重要，最重要是太后答小豪子其他的考卷都答錯啊，太后決定要轉台了！

【點・知你】
香港面對各種挑戰，疫情、社會事件、經濟狀況正面對「不安的天氣」。歌手方皓玟點唱《假使世界原來不像你預期》，鼓勵香港人在逆境下不要退縮，面對不公義的事要發聲，繼續做好自己，勿忘初心。
（歌曲：假使世界原來不像你預期　　主唱：方皓玟）

【頭條劇場】走過從前
1994年《獅子山下》題為《走過從前》的一集，老牌英資洋行找來 Helen為集團編寫歷史書，但高層向Helen施壓，認為強調與香港及內地的關係，更有利公司在內地的發展…
近日，DSE歷史科一條題目引起爭議，教育局史無前例建議取消題目；行政長官林鄭月娥表明，自己沒有介入處理，強調並非政治干預教育。公正、準確的歷史，希望下一代也能看見。

不可以留住昨天…
人稱「飛哥」的前行政立法兩局議員李鵬飛逝世，享年80歲。飛哥縱橫政壇大半生，他曾祝願香港有「大和解」，希望政黨與政府加強溝通，減少社會分化，此祝願何時會實現…
（歌曲：似水流年　　主唱：梅艷芳）

【未來現在學】《1984》的平行時空
喬治．奧威爾所寫的《1984》是人類文學的經典。小說當中的三大國：大洋國、歐亞國和東亞國中間有個緩衝區，有如虛構的「香港」，自成一角，但已成為附庸，忘卻自身命運。《1984》的世界，「真理部」篡改歷史、審查新聞出版、監控無處不在，人類沒有自由。
《1984》前瞻未來，但未來是否已來？

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第16集—全力支持
Content description:
全力支持
眾主持同場表示支持，香江維護天朝安全法，天朝安全，絕不妥協！

【頭條劇場】國與家
1992年《獅子山下》題為《家》的一集，女主角面對親情與移民的抉擇，劇中的情節是否反映現時香港人的心態？如何才能安居樂業，把一個地方叫「家」？
近日中央出手制訂「港區國安法」，特首認為國家安全是每個國家的頭等大事，亦是市民安居樂業的基礎，但有人則擔心國安法破壞一國兩制，甚至有被以言入罪的機會。

真的愛你
在香港，國歌法在立法會二讀通過，同日，港區國安法在北京通過。政府、各界全面力撐支持，香港市民繼續上街「反國安法、反國歌法」。還未有具體方案內容的港區國安法，「真的愛你」究竟要如何表達才是對？
（歌曲：真的愛你　　主唱：Beyond）

【My TV SUFFER】
「食唔落」—阿媽教煮廿幾年都未能成功炮製的「本地臘鴨」﹗
《擔心字典》—講個「猿」字﹗

【點・知你】
今年是六四事件31周年，在限聚令仍然生效下，六四那片燭海將無法再次點亮維園。歌手鄭敬基點唱《媽媽我沒有做錯》──一首創作於民運後的歌曲，他覺得當年在天安門廣場上的學生，與今日參與抗爭的青年人沒有兩樣，同樣是追求民主、自由。今年，不論六四集會能否舉行，香港人心都已經被喚醒，因為香港人已置身其中。
（歌曲：媽媽我沒有做錯　　主唱：鄭敬基）

【未來現在學】《論暴政》
提摩希．史奈德2017年著作《論暴政：二十世紀的二十個教訓》，為今天紛擾憂患的世局提供做人處世的生活指南﹗請緊記，不盲從權威、相信事實、更要保持微笑！

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第17集—遍地開花
Content description:
太后與徐副官：六四包袱
今年六四，太后又成功考第一了，30年來一直放不下的包袱，今年第一次放下...

【頭條劇場】12357890
1994年《獅子山下》題為《九七同學會》的一集，講述一班新聞系同學，由1980至1997年之間的經歷，透過一群老朋友不同的際遇，描寫時代的變遷，當中發生的八九民運，震撼人心。
今年是六四31週年，在政府推行限聚令下，維園沒有了行禮如儀的紀念集會，但燭光反而遍地開花，延續當年追求民主自由的火種。

【點・知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
樂隊KOLOR於去年反送中運動期間創作了歌曲《進退》，表達香港人共同進退的精神。反送中運動持續了近一年，中央訂立港區國安法，他們認為這首歌仍然可作為現時的寫照。面對言論和創作空間可能被收窄，大家有或進或退的掙扎，但仍然要有夢想，不要忘記初衷。
（歌曲：進退　　主唱：KOLOR）

【My TV SUFFER】擔心字典
天色已漸沉，齊齊來HAVE FUN，侵侵侵...
今集《擔心字典》先同你講個「侵」字！仲有淪落街頭特別版，可憐下啦！

STAND BY 國安法
日前全國人大通過港區國安法後，雖然當中細節條文未出台，但政府高官、紀律部隊首長、港區人大、政協等，紛紛出聲明、擺街站聯署，鋪天蓋地宣傳支持國安法，將民間反對聲音通通蓋過～誓要stand by 國安法！
（歌曲：Stand By Me　　主唱：梅艷芳）

【未來現在學】《高堡奇人》
著名科幻小說作家菲利普．迪克於1962年創作了架空歷史的小說《高堡奇人》，傳頌至今。書中世界板塊、政權顛覆常態，而書中書的平行時空沒有永恆，理論、制度、模式都敵不過鐘擺理論。
正在閱讀這行文字的你，會否期待鐘擺出現？

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第18集—雙重身分
Content description:
太后與小豪子：雙重身份
小豪子侍奉太后多年，最近多了一個身分，就是同時侍奉國家，那就要先學懂使用「學習強國」這個APP。

【頭條劇場】國安法北風
1994年《獅子山下》題為《借東風》一集，故事講述女主角開拓內地市場，但工作伙伴無故在上海失蹤，眾人無法理解內地的遊戲規則。同時女主角與內地商人的一段情，亦由互生情愫轉為虛無不安。
近日中央出手訂立港區國安法，港澳辦副主任張曉明認為法例是殺毒軟件，特首林鄭月娥亦繼續推銷立法是合情合理，香港人能夠適應新的遊戲規則嗎？

【點・知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
2019年6月12日，去年今日，《逃犯條例》原訂立法會二讀。
這一年，香港爆發反修例運動，社會嚴重撕裂。「曾感動、曾憤怒、曾傷心與沮喪，彷彿每日都經歷一百種情緒…」歌手藍奕邦點唱《六月》，回顧這一年，願香港人都能忠於自己、有話直說。

My TV SUFFER
阿耳，國家終於有任務給你！你的士大夫身分終於大派用場啦！
擔心字典—「非常之非常之…」又叫做：太！

因航
因航—因為肺炎疫情，而業務大受影響需要港府注資的國泰航空。作為本港航運業的龍頭大哥，接受政府出手救援後，能否起死回生？
（歌曲：夕陽之歌　　主唱：梅艷芳）

【未來現在學】獨裁者2.0
2012年政治學者道布森出版了《獨裁者的進化－收編、分化、假民主》一書，書中指由獨裁者1.0發展到2.0，不再是過往獨裁者的模樣。披著羊皮的狼，人民可以怎麼分辨？作者指獨裁者2.0也有其一套模式，而且擅於利用網絡。未來，還會出現獨裁者3.0嗎？

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: 第19集—最後一集…？
Content description:
最後一集…？
頭條新聞播出31年，說要「執笠」原來都說了很多次，只是一直未成事。但今次太后並不樂觀，因為今時跟往日不同，以前是說說笑，現在是不能說笑。
後會有期！

【點・知你】要點一首歌給香港人，你會點…？
1980年韓國光州起義與今天香港的抗爭畫面放在一起，異常相似。
歌手黃耀明點唱其新歌《自由之夏》，原曲為電影《1987逆權公民》片尾曲，由林夕填詞，寄語香港人不要被恐懼打敗，在艱難的時候，更加要緊扣在一起。
（歌曲：自由之夏　　主唱：黃耀明）

【My TV SUFFER】擔心字典最終回
曾教授 x 林班長 x 太后 x 小豪子
前途未卜，不要做《擔心字典》了，改為擔心自己吧﹗

【未來現在學】如果蘇聯有大數據
如果蘇聯仍然存在，社會主義國家將會如何利用大數據去「發展」社會？如果蘇聯用大數據制定更精密的五年計劃，經濟是否會更蓬勃？如果蘇聯用大數據去實現政治理想，如果……

講者：沈旭暉（中大社會科學院客席副教授）

Title: To Sell Or Not To Sell (11/11/2010)
EDUCATION (2)– learning to study of one’s own volition (2/12/2010)
FOOD WASTAGE (24/02/2011)
Content description:
We pay for food, but we pay for unwanted food as well.  Did you know that the eateries in Hong Kong are producing 3000 tons of leftovers every day and the Government is spending 2.4 million dollars to deal with the unwanted food?  

Producer:	 Clara Li

Title: 15 Years of “One Country, Two Systems”(1)
Content description: 15 Years of “One Country, Two Systems”

Title: National Education, shall we?
Content description:
Is there a need in Hong Kong for moral and national education to be taught in schools as an independent subject? The Government says yes and a course directive has in fact been issued. Many parents and students say no. Schools are caught in the middle of a controversy.     
 
Producer: Eric Poon

Title: Aversion to Red
Content description:
The Legislation Council elections in the Hong Kong SAR have just concluded. Competition was bitter. Among all the battle cries and slogans, latent sentiments came to the surface. 
 
Producer: Gillian Yau

Title: Conserving Hong Kong’s Cultural Heritage
Content description:
For all the rapid development, there are still many old buildings in Hong Kong. Some are grand structures while others are rather dilapidated residential blocks, but a good number of them could be considered to be of historical value. Which should be removed for redevelopment and which should be kept? 
 
Producer: Dora Choi

Title: Made in Bangladesh
Hong Kong’s Political Magazines
The Sounds of Life
Content description:
What is music to one person could well be noise to another. What, then, are we to make of the sounds that we hear in our environment? Are they cacophonous … or symphonic? 
 
Producer:  Phoebe Chan

Title: PM 2.5
Content description:
Hong Kong, like all big cities in the world, is engaged in a battle against air pollution. On land as well as water, harmful particulate matter, or PM, is being emitted from diesel engines that power vehicles and ships. That’s PM2.5 on Hong Kong Connection. 
 
Producer:  Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Reform of NGOs in China
Content description:
There are not many non-government organizations in China. The main reason is a simple one: registration is prohibitively difficult. For so-called sensitive groups like gay people and workers, it might even seem impossible … despite a recently introduced new policy.
 
Producer:  Flora Yeung

Title: The Identity Conundrum
Free Television in Hong Kong
The Great Famine 1959
Content description:
A little more than half a century ago, political movements swept across China like continuous tidal waves, wreaking havoc throughout the country. Famine spread like a deadly plague. What really caused it, nature or man? 
 
Producer: Gillian Yau

Title: Black Sheep in the Flock
Make Way for Development
Content description:
There is undeniably a shortage of land in Hong Kong. For development, the Government has been requisitioning farmland in the New Territories. Some people are happy but others are not. 
 
Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Not on deities or emperors But on ourselves do we rely
Conservation and Controversy
Content description:
For all the rapid development, there are still many old buildings in Hong Kong. Some are grand structures while others are rather dilapidated residential blocks, but a good number of them could be considered to be of historical value. Which should be removed for redevelopment and which should be kept? 
 
Producer: Dora Choi

Title: Costly Roof
Time to Reflect
Content description:
The world did not end on 21st December 2012 as some people following the ancient Mayan Calendar had feared. Life goes on. But in Hong Kong, there are people who think it is time for us to do some soul-searching. 
 
Producer: Phoebe Chan

Title: Next Station, Sheung Shui
Content description:
The meteoric rise of consumerism in mainland China in recent years has brought dramatic changes to Sheung Shui on the Hong Kong side of the border. The town has become a bootlegging hub. 

Producer: Clara Li

Title: My Canine Angel
Content description:
A guide dog is to blind person much more than his best friend; it is his eyes, his navigator and guardian angel. In Hong Kong, however, the service of guide dogs, though widely appreciated, is still not fully developed. 

Producer: Vicky IP

Title: Activism on the Rise
Content description:
There are some 6,000 demonstrations and protest marches in Hong Kong every year. Many of them are in fact held in contravention of the existing Public Security Ordinance.
 
Producer: Dora Choi

Title: The Embattled CY
Content description:
On 16th January 2013, C. Y. Leung, the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong SAR, delivered his first policy address after six months in office. As expected, the reception was mixed, with supporters and opponents vociferously expressing their views. 
 
Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: The Mandatory Provident Fund
Content description:
The Mandatory Provident Fund System came into effect in Hong Kong in December 2000 to provide the entire workforce with some form of retirement protection. How well or poorly has it performed? How can it be improved?

Producer: Fanny Kwan

Title: Poor But Proud
Content description:
Children of poor families are underprivileged, and unless given a helping hand, they generally labour through life in intergenerational poverty. The Child Development Fund established in 2008 was designed to tackle this very problem.

Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Snake King Lam… a Hong Kong legend
Content description:
Snake is an expensive traditional delicacy in Hong Kong, and to the elderly and people well versed in local culture and tradition, Snake King Lam, the snake shop that is over 100 years old, is a legend. 

Producer: Clara Li

Title: The Network Vista of Hope
Content description:
After the Chinese Communist Party vowed again recently to address the perennial problem of corruption in China, the response from the citizenry has been overwhelming. Corrupt officials are now on tenterhooks, fearing evidence of their debauchery might go viral overnight on the social media network. 

Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Enough is Enough
Content description:
In December last Year (2012), a female university student was gang raped and subsequently died. The heinous crime has brought the world’s attention to the sexism that is endemic in Indian culture. 

Producer: Phoebe Chan

Title: The Insurmountable Barrier
Content description:
With Hong Kong being a special administrative region of China, Chinese has become a prerequisite for advancement in the mainstream education system. To children of the ethnic minorities, however, learning Chinese is virtually an Insurmountable barrier. 



Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: My Mother is Innocent
Content description:
In China at present, people audaciously challenging the establishment by petitioning for justice can be arrested for anything from disturbing the peaceto sedition. In this documentary, a look is taken at their children who languish at home without proper parental care.

Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: The Sinking of Lamma IV
Content description:
The 1st of October, China’s National Day, was marred by a tragedy in Hong Kong waters off the shores of Lamma Island last year. A collision led to the sinking of a ferry. 39 people died. A year on, the bereaved families are still waiting for a definitive report from the Government.

Producer: Paul Lee

Title: For the sake of my children
Content description:
For a good number of years, expectant mothers from the mainland have been coming to Hong Kong to give birth to their children so that these children can become permanent residents. Having achieved their aim, however, many of these women … together with their husbands … are finding themselves in a predicament. 

Producer: Fanny Kwan

Title: Homemaker Dads
Content description:
The woman’s place is at home and it’s the man’s job to bring home the bacon.’ Fewer and fewer people in the modern world seem to subscribe to such conservative thinking anymore. Many women are breadwinners and more and more men are choosing to station themselves at home as homemaker dads, minding their children and doing house chores. 


Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Bon Voyage
Content description:
Government statistics show that emigration is on the rise again in Hong Kong. In the first six months of this year, 3900 left. In numbers, this is nothing compared with the exodus in earlier years, of course, but there is a trend of considerable socio-political significance

Producer: Fanny Kwan

Title: Beasts without Burden
Content description:
Little farming is done in Hong Kong now, at least not the traditional kind. Farmers have gone on to do various other things, but what has happened to their faithful friends, the cattle? 

Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Split
Content description:
Hong Kong as a society is becoming split. On the active political scene, protagonists and antagonists of the establishment are often engaged in heated altercation. In intervening, are the police heroes or callous enforcers? 

Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Speaking with Clay
Content description:
The people who do speak are volunteers dedicated to helping mentally challenged children express themselves through the art of pottery, which is, in essence, speaking with clay. 

Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Who is the Loser
Light Pollution
Content description:
The glitzy lights in Hong Kong at night have few peers in brightness, but Hong Kong as a city has few peers in Light Pollution as well. 

Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: Kwu Tung…earmarked for redevelopment
Content description:
Kwu Tung is a town in the north-eastern part of the New Territories, an area earmarked for redevelopment. The people there are facing imminent removal with trepidation. 

Producer: Yip Man

Title: Kwun Tong…under urban renewal
Content description:
Urban renewal is going on in earnest in Hong Kong. For the SAR as a whole, this can only mean improvement, but for the residents and shopkeepers within the areas involved, urban renewal is a ‘Monster’ wreaking all sorts of havoc.

Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Two-pronged Treatment
Content description:
The Hong Kong SAR Government has been gradually bringing traditional Chinese medicine back to the medical system. Leading practitioners of modern medicine have proved there are significant advantages in incorporating traditional Chinese medical practices into the mainstream. 

Producer: Clara Li

Title: Food Safety
Content description:
Even as people the world over are becoming increasingly aware of food safety, more and more tainted foodstuff is appearing on the market. Why? What lessons on food safety can we learn from scientists? 

Producer: Phoebe Chan

Title: Food Safety (2)
Content description:
Food safety has led to an awakening of consciousness in Taiwan and Hong Kong. The questions are asked: Should the agricultural industry be revived? Can we challenge the economics of mass production? 

Producer: Phoebe Chan

Title: Project Phoenix
Content description:
Internationally, Hong Kong has never been a force to be reckoned with in football, the beautiful game. Project Phoenix, introduced by the Government four years ago, was designed to change all that. 


Producer: Paul Lee

Title: The Arduous Road to Integrated Education
Content description:
The Government introduced the Integrated Education Scheme ten years ago in an effort to place children with learning difficulties into the mainstream school system. So far, not much success can be claimed. 

Producer: Clara Li

Title: Fermi…A voice for the ethnic minorities
Content description:
We have on several occasions talked about the ethnic minorities in Hong Kong. This time, we focus on education for the young people among them. In Fermi Wong, a social worker, they have a champion.

Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: The Enclaves
Content description:
There are 24 country parks in Hong Kong. Scattered among them are 52 old indigenous villages, most of which look oddly derelict and out of place. They are referred to as “Enclaves”.

Producer: Dora Choi

Title: Boism after Bo
Content description:
Bo Xi-lai was once the top dog in China’s direct-controlled municipality of Chongqing. He has fallen from grace. Was he a hero or a villain? How is the city now without him? 

Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: New Hongkongers
Content description:
More and more people from Mainland China are becoming permanent residents in Hong Kong. People’s Daily has referred to them as New Hongkongers, new blood to sustain Hong Kong’s growth. What do the local people think? 

Producer: Gillian Yau

Title: Mainland Students in Taiwan
Content description:
Young people in Mainland China now have the opportunity of going to university in Taiwan. We will meet a few of them to see how they are doing and what they think of life on the island. 

Producer: Elaine Ko

Title: Freedom of the Press
Content description:
Press Freedom in Hong Kong, according to Reporters Without Borders, is on the decline. Two controversial personnel changes in the media recently seem to attest to the validity of the statement.

Producer: Fanny Kwan, Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: The ICAC
Content description:
The Independent Commission Against Corruption, the ICAC, was formed in February 1974. On its 40th anniversary, we review some of its accomplishments and look at a big challenge it is currently facing. 

Producer: Paul Lee

Title: Street Theatre
Content description:
Sai Yeung Choi Street South in Mongkok was designated as a Pedestrian Area every day for 13 years. It became quite a hot spot, a venue for Street Theatre. But now, vehicular traffic has returned.

Producer: Phoebe Chan

Title: The Moment of Truth
Content description: The definitive word has finally come from Beijing on the issue of electing the SAR’s next Chief Executive.  For the democratic bloc, the National People’s Congress’ interpretation of universal suffrage has brought nothing but disillusionment, and the Moments of Truth has arrived.

Title: Baptism Of  Fire
Content description: The students of Hong Kong have hit the headlines all over the world.  Many of them have become new soldiers of democracy, with boycotting classes and staging protests as their first experience of action politics.

Title: The Democratic Umbrella
Content description: The pro-democracy Occupy Movement in Hong Kong is not confined to Central District anymore.  It is spreading, and the colourful umbrellas held up by the protesters have captured the imagination of the International media.

Title: The Embattled Police
Content description: The political atmosphere in Hong Kong now is such that the police often find themselves physically standing between two opposing camps ... the democrats and the establishmentarians.  They are our embattled police.

Title: 25 Years On- Words From Prison
Content description: Twenty-five years have passed, but the powers that be in China have still failed to face up to the June 4th Incident.  But try as they might, they really can’t prevent people from thinking and talking about what happened at Tiananmen Square.

Title: 25 Years On - Our Tiananmen 1989
Content description: Many in Hong Kong are making an effort to ensure that the June 4th Incident in Beijing 25 years ago will not be erased from history.  They are doing so for the sake of Hong Kong.

Title: Social Enterprises At Work
Content description: Social enterprises are supposed to be viable businesses that are also altruistic.  There are over 400 of them in Hong Kong now, but even with government subsidies, many are struggling.

Title: The Class of 1986 (1)
Content description: We get to know some of the law graduates at the University of Hong Kong in 1986.  Most of them now lawyers in their prime, they have personally witnessed and experienced the historic handover of sovereignty in Hong Kong and are facing the same issues about democracy as all of us.

Title: The Class of 1986 (2)
Content description: We get to know some of the law graduates at the University of Hong Kong in 1986.  Most of them now lawyers in their prime, they have personally witnessed and experienced the historic handover of sovereignty in Hong Kong and are facing the same issues about democracy as all of us.

Title: Beijing-Shrouded in Haze
Content description: Beijing is plagued by serious air pollution.  The concerted efforts to spruce up the city for the 2008 Olympics have had little lasting effect.  The city seems constantly shrouded in haze .  Join us next week for a report on Hong Kong Connection.

Title: History Unearthed
Content description: At the construction site of the Shatin to Central Link To Kwa Wan Station, a treasure trove of relics and articles of high historical significance has been found.  Should construction continue?  Or should preservation take precedence?

Title: Autistic Children (1)
Content description: Autism is a pervasive developmental disorder that plagues children in their early years. There is treatment, but still no cure. For people with autistic children, parenting is a battle that cannot be fought without boundless love.

Title: Autistic Children (2)
Content description: Meet Mr and Mrs Tse.  They have three sons, each of them medically considered a patient of autism.  But Mr and Mrs Tse are not complaining about how difficult it is to take care of their children.  Instead, they consider themselves blessed to have them.

Title: Give Me A Home
Content description: There are numerous unfortunate babies in every part of the world who need the warmth of home and the loving care that parents provide.  But adopting a child is not an easy decision to make.  We meet two married couples who have made that decision and learn a thing or two from their experience.

Title: Flotsam & Jetsam ... in Hong Kong waters
Content description: There are some very lovely beaches in Hong Kong, but unfortunately they are not the cleanest in the world.  Part of the rubbish is locally produced, and another big part comes from the sea.

Title: End Of Act 1
Content description: The Occupy Movement in Hong Kong, known also as the Umbrella Movement, is over.  The protesters are gone and the streets have been cleared, but few would believe we have seen the final act.

Title: Rare Diseases
Content description: There are at present over 6000 rare diseases known to the medical world.  For a patient of a rare disease, before treatment of any sort can begin, diagnosis itself is usually a huge challenge to the doctor.

Title: The Bloggers
Content description: Blogging is all the rage at the moment.  Many bloggers have become celebrities of sorts and some are trying to make use of their fame to move on to fortune by introducing or actually endorsing commercial products.

Title: Homework
Content description: Primary school children in Hong Kong have to far too much homework to do every day, many people say.  The pressure of homework can indeed make life rather miserable for children and parents alike.

Title: Sai Wan ... where the glitter ends
Content description: Spearheaded by an MTR link, change has descended on Sai Wan on the western side of Hong Kong Island.It has brought about a huge increase in property value, disrupting the lives of many old residents.

Title: Precious Water
Content description: Hong Kong has been getting an adequate supply of water from the river Dongjiang for some considerable time, and it is relatively cheap.  Is there any danger of over-reliance?  Are there other sources available to Hong Kong apart from Dongjiang and rain?

Title: Liberal Studies and Politics
Content description: Liberal Studies, a subject included in the secondary school curriculum, is itself currently a subject of heated debate.  Naysayers allege it is being politicised and students are being radicalised as a result.

Title: Title
Content description: By law, all residential buildings that have reached the age of 30 have to be inspected for safety reasons.  To pass the inspection, maintenance invariably has to be done ... and this can be very costly.

Title: Housing-Hong Kong’s Perennial Problem
Content description: For ordinary people in Hong Kong, it is not easy to find a place to live.  Many families and individuals get by in tiny rooms in sub-divided units. Some are penny-pinching every day in order to make their mortgage payments.  Yes, there is public housing, but supply never seems adequate.

Title: Dear  ‘Me’ Letter
Content description: Now that they are not in the spotlight around the world, what are those young warriors for democracy in Hong Kong thinking and doing?  To learn about their present thoughts and see if they will change in time, we have asked a number of them to each write a letter to their future selves.

Title: ‘Mission’ Accomplished?
Content description: Asia Television Limited, or ATV, is in dire straits.  Financially strapped, it is struggling to pay its staff.  And yet, the strong man behind the scenes says he has accomplished a historical mission.  What does he mean?

Title: Onwards, Singapore!
Content description:
Singapore has just celebrated its 50th anniversary ... without Lee Kuan Yew, the premier who passed away on March this year. The new leadership will be embracing Lee’s legacy, but the new era will bring them unprecedented challenges.   


Producer: Gillian Yau

Title: 70 Years On- Remembering the War
Content description:
The 2nd World War ended in 1945 and with it, China’s 8-year war of resistance against Japanese invasion also came to an end. As Beijing commemorates victory in style this year, there are young people on the mainland, in Taiwan and in Hong Kong who are determined to learn about those bloody years. 


Producer: Gillian Yau, Fanny Kwan

Title: 70 Years On- Spectre of War
Content description:
Japan is reportedly on the cusp of foregoing pacifism. Despite what Prime Minister Abe is doing to amend the country’s defence policy, the voice of opposition is strong, particularly from the young.  

Producer: Gillian Yau, Fanny Kwan

Title: Seeking Haven…Vietnamese People in Hong Kong
Content description:
Hong Kong was for over two decades plagued by an influx of Vietnamese seeking refuge. The problem seems to be over now, but while many Vietnamese refugees have integrated admirably into life in Hong Kong, some have never found the haven they wanted.



Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: The Right To Have Children In China
Content description:
China’s one-child policy has been in place for over 30 years?  Has it worked?  Yes, if we consider only controlling population growth.  But that’s not what we should do. 

Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Chinese Dama
Content description: China’s new macro-economic policy has tapped into a considerable pool of idle cash in the possession of a large army of middle-aged women affectionately called dama.  These mothers and grandmothers have become avid and, in most cases, irrational players in the stock, bullion and property markets.

Title: Salt and Sugar
Content description: The World Health Organisation says that the people of Hong Kong are consuming far too much salt and sugar.  In response, the Government has begun a campaign to increase public awareness, and at least two people have boldly opened a new restaurant that serves food that challenges the traditional idea of palatability.

Title: The Tree That Gave Hong Kong Its Name
Content description:
Incense is all the rage in China. The trees that produce it in the wild are virtually all gone. Poachers are now coming across the border to plunder Hong Kong’s healthy woods and country parks.


Producer: Michelle Chan

Title: The Lead Hazard
Content description:
Excessive lead found in drinking water at 11 housing estates and several educational institutions has brought about an outcry in Hong Kong. The Gov't have taken a series of remedial measures but the public remain on edge.


Producer: Paul Lee

Title: Let’s Play!
Content description:
It’s the child’s right to play, says the United Nations, and children should ideally be allowed to play for at least one hour per day. Many young parents in Hong Kong are taking this message to heart.


Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: New Blood
Content description:
The 2015 District Council Elections finished in November, with both the establishmentarian and the pan-democratic camps celebrating victory with newcomers. Could this be the advent of a new era?


Producer: Paul Lee, Fanny Kwan

Title: If Tree Could Speak
Content description:
There are problems with tree management in Hong Kong. Understanding the importance of greening and the value of the trees among them, many people are voicing their concern.


Producer: Kwong Chui-kuen

Title: Caring for the Intellectually Impaired
Content description:
Thanks to medical science, intellectually impaired people are able to live longer. This is good news. But on the flip side of the progress, caring for them is putting their families and social services under increasing strain.

Producer: Grace Wong

Title: The Gift of Life
Content description:
In Hong Kong, as in other cities all over the world, there are many critically ill people in desperate need of organ transplantation. Our organ donation rate, however, is among the lowest in the world. 


Producer: Heiman Leung

Title: Luminescence in the Night(1)
Content description:
Mark Mak is an unusual young man. A conservationist, he’s a champion of fireflies and the founder of the Firefly Museum on Lantau Island.


Producer: Choy Yuk-ling

Title: Luminescence in the Night (2)
Content description: Mark Mak, the champion of fireflies in Hong Kong, is no longer fighting his battles alone.  He is happily married and has a son.

Title: Disappeared
Content description: In October last year, five staffers of a bookstore in Causeway Bay went missing under mysterious circumstances.  There is some evidence five are on the mainland, but their exact whereabouts are unknown.  What is happening?

Title: Copyright in Cyber Space
Content description: There is heated debate over the Copyright Amendment draft bill that has just been tabled at the Legislative Council.  Basically, it is a debate between copyright protection and freedom of expression.

Title: The Hawkers at Shum Shui Po
Content description: Ugly scenes erupted recently in Shum Shui Po when officers from the Food and Environment Hygiene Department were confronted by angry hawkers.

Title: Industrious Hong Kong
Content description: The people of Hong Kong work long hours, arguably longer than people anywhere else in the world.  Are they happy?  Is anything being done to keep the lengthening working day in check?

Title: The Fishball Revolution
Content description: On the first day of the Lunar New Year, rioting broke out in Mongkok when the police attempted to evict food vendors from the area.  The incident has once again brought the polarisation in Hong Kong to the fore.

Title: Empty Schools
Content description: There are 234 empty school structures in Hong Kong.  Many of them have been left to gather dust for over 35 years.  Why is such precious space being wasted?  How can the lifeless premises be revitalised?

Title: Brownfield
Content description: Swathes of the countryside in the New Territories are now occupied by container depots, storage sites, garages and the like.  Known as Brownfield, such land is expanding.  Its total area is now already the size of 60 Victoria Parks.

Title: Setting The Records Straight
Content description:
How much do we know about the history of Hong Kong? Should we refer to Britain’s account or China’s account? Neither, say many Hong Kong people of this generation. They want to set the records straight.


Producer: Dora Choi

Title: The Cultural Revolution ... 50 Years On (I)
The Cultural Revolution ... 50 Years On (II)
Content description:
China’s Cultural Revolution was, according to the powers that be, ‘10 years of turmoil’ ... ten years of rampaging red guards and destruction of the nation’s age-old culture. Fifty years on, is it really over?

Producer: Chan Bo-shun

Title: Eddie Chu, The New Champion Horse
Content description:
Eddie Chu is a new Legislative Councillor, having won his seat easily in the New Territories West.  Never afraid to speak his mind, he has already ruffled the feathers of many powerful people.  

Producer: Fanny Kwan

Title: One Belt, One Road: Xi’s Concerto
Content description:
China has become an economic powerhouse, and it is trying to create a new geopolitical order from Asia to Europe to challenge the dominance of the west.  ‘One Belt, One Road’ is apparently a strategic initiative with this in mind.  

Producer: Gillian Yau, Dora Choi, Fanny Kwan

Title: One Belt, One Road: For Better or Worse
Content description:
We continue with China’s ‘One Belt, One Road’ this week by taking a look at what people in Kazakhstan and Vietnam think.  Do they buy into President Xi Jin-ping’s pitch that the initiative will bring them a better life?  

Producer: Gillian Yau, Dora Choi, Fanny Kwan

Title: One Belt, One Road: No Strings Attached
Content description:
China’s One Belt One Road is an ambitious initiative.  President Xi Jin-ping has reassured all partner countries that China’s goal is happiness for all.  Do Myanmar and Iran find his reassurance plausible?  

Producer: Gillian Yau, Dora Choi, Fanny Kwan

Title: I Do Solemnly Swear…
Content description:
The National People’s Congress has, for the fifth time, intervened in the Hong Kong judiciary by interpreting the Basic Law.  The reason this time was the bizarre way two young newly elected Legislative Councillors approached their swearing-in ceremony.

Producer: Paul Lee, Flora Yeung, Dora Choi, Fanny Kwan

Title: You’re Actually An Angel
Content description:
Not many people are aware there are babies born with disorders of sex development, or DSD.  They are also known as intersex babies.  Intersex are hardly ever openly discussed.  Few if any relevant government statistics are available.  Indeed, not until recently have we seen people with the genetic condition come out of the closet.

Producer: Grace Wong

Title: Time To Move
Content description:
The Government is cracking down on unauthorised use of space in industrial buildings. To start with, eleven buildings are targeted. For the entertainment establishments, eateries and even churches in them, it’s time to move.

Producer: Ko Chit

Title: The Closed Area
Content description:
In the 1940’s, the British colonial government set up a closed area as a buffer zone at the border in the New Territories.  Today, the SAR Government has decided to open up a good portion of it for development.  

Producer: Candy Chan

Title: Light Housing
Content description:
Meet Ricky Yu, a man dedicated to helping people in need. Be introduced to ‘Light Be’, the social enterprise he has founded, and learn about his projects ‘light homes’ and ‘Light Housing’. 

Producer: Heiman Leung

Title: The Battle To Be Electors
Content description:
Much is happening in Hong Kong’s political scene.  A new Chief Executive is to be elected in March next year ... an election decided not by 7 million people, but by a small Election Committee.  

Producer: Paul Lee, Fanny Kwan, Grace Wong

Title: E-Learning
Content description:
A new era of education has dawned in Hong Kong.  Some educators are welcoming it with enthusiasm.  Meet them and learn about some of the challenges they face.

Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Innovation
Content description:
When it comes to technology, Hong Kong does not rank very high in the world.  But there is really no lack of talent. The question is how to keep them and how to fund research and development.  

Producer: Candy Chan

Title: Home Owners Corporations
Content description:
There’s good news to report about life in Hong Kong. Home Owners Corporations of a number of housing estates seem to be improving in accordance with the principles of democracy.

Producer: Fanny Kwan

Title: In Defence Of Conscience
Content description: There is no lack of human rights lawyers and advocates in China, but as the crackdown on the 9th of July last year showed, challenging the authorities is a risky proposition.

Title: Mini Flats
Content description: Residential flats in Hong Kong seem to be getting smaller and smaller.  Many of them are designed to be studio flats.  Though expensive, they are in great demand.

Title: The Grand Old Teahouse
Content description:
Enjoying tea and dim sum is very much a part of Hong Kong’s Cantonese culture. But few if any restaurant can last for 80 years like Shun Hing.


Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Hawkers and Bazaars
Content description:
Food is always an important item in celebrating the New Year’s ... perhaps more so in Hong Kong than anywhere else. Hawkers of culinary delights are by and large welcome in most grassroots communities, but what do the authorities think?


Producer:Grace Wong

Title: Disappeared (2017)
Content description:
According to the media, Xiao Jianhua, the founder of a financial group named Tomorrow Holdings, was suspected to be abducted by the Chinese authorities.
The incident happened a year after the disappearance of five missing booksellers in Hong Kong.
This is a re-run programme, first broadcasted on 18th February 2016, awarded the Silver Hugo of Chicago International Film Festival 2016.

Disappeared (2016)
In October 2015, five staffers of a bookstore in Causeway Bay went missing under mysterious circumstances.  There is some evidence five are on the mainland, but their exact whereabouts are unknown.  What is happening?  


Director: Paul Lee

Title: Domestic Helpers in Hong Kong
Content description:
The Government has permitted foreign domestic helpers to work in Hong Kong since the 1970's to meet the shortage of local full-time live-in domestic helpers. Currently， there are over 350 000 foreign domestic helpers in Hong Kong， assisting over 280 000 households with housework and taking care of the elderly and children in their families. 
 After a hot debate in society， starting from this year， the Standard Employment Contract for foreign domestic helpers will include a new clause on cleaning outward-facing windows to safeguard their occupational safety. How will it affect both sides？ 
After receiving hundreds of complaints from jobseekers and domestic helpers about the agencies， Labour Department has newly promulgated Code of Practice for Employment Agencies last month. The code lists established legal requirements as well as “minimum standards” which the commissioner for labour expects agencies to meet. These standards include transparency in business operations， drawing up service agreements with jobseekers and employers， and providing payment receipts. Will this voluntary code bring more protection to the consumers？

Title: Big Data
Content description:
Big Data, massive gathering and analyzing of data in real time, allows us addressing some of humanity biggest challenges. This documentary captures the promise and peril of this extraordinary knowledge 

Producer: Michelle Chan

Title: STEM
Content description:
STEM education is now the new trend. EDB has put resources to encourage schools to launch this program in order to train the communicating thinking of students. What problems do the teachers face under STEM education? And what the students need to equip more?



Producer: Flora Yeung

Title: Waste Charging=Waste Reduction?
Content description:
According to the latest EPD figure, the amount of waste per person disposed daily keeps increasing, which is the worst in a decade. The EPD announced waste-charging legislation should be enacted as soon as possible to help reduce waste generation. The suggested waste charge will be 1-2 HKD per household per day. What are the public views? While the government has implemented a number of measures over the decade to prepare for such legislation, what is its effectiveness?

Producer: Candy Chan

Title: Judicial Review
Content description: With increasing Judicial Review cases, this episode seeks to explain the basic principles of its operation, as well as its merits to improve governance. Many judicial review cases seem to be highly political, yet in reality many cases concern important public interests related to education and housing issues, labour rights, human rights and more. The program will further examine whether the system is being abused, with illustration with significant cases.

Title: 20 Years After The Return (1)
Content description: Hong Kong officially returned to China on the 1 st of July 1997. Twenty of the first 50 years have gone by. How much has changed in Hong Kong?

Title: 20 Years After The Return (2) – Treading A Tightrope
Content description: Freedom of expression, one of the most important principles of democracy, is supposedly enshrined in the Basic Law, the de facto constitution by which the Hong Kong SAR is to be governed. Is it now under threat?

Title: 20 Years After The Return (3) –One country, two systems
Content description:
The existence of Hong Kong as a special administrative region of China came
about as a result of Deng Xiao-ping’s pragmatism. But how do the people of Hong
Kong feel about ‘one country, two systems’ so far?

Title: Promoting Sports In Hong Kong
Content description:
The Government seems determined to promote sport as an integral part of life in the SAR. However, there is still a lack of top-class facilities and not every new
proposal is meeting with public approval.

Title: The Giant Who Had No Enemies
Content description: Liu Xiaobo, the famous Chinese scholar, dissident and Nobel laureate, is dead. He frequently said China was in need of a moral giant. Little did he realise that for numerous Chinese, he was that very giant himself.

Title: The Tug-of-war With Bugs
Content description: For some three quarters of a century, antibiotics have done humankind great service. Due to various reasons, however, they are fast losing their efficacy against superbugs. Alarm bells are ringing.

Title: Ageing In Place
Content description:
People are living longer and longer.  While longevity is something to be celebrated, an ageing population is a considerable problem for any modern city or country. 
According to Hong Kong Population Projections, the population is expected to remain on an ageing trend. The proportion of the population aged 65 and over is projected to rise markedly to 2.58 million in 2064. The needs of long term elderly care are projected with declining mortality rate in our aging population.
Most of the people want to age at home instead of spending their last part of lives in old age homes. In Hong Kong, a policy referred to as ageing in place was introduced in 2003.  But have the burden of the caregivers been addressed?

Title: The Investment Of Sweat & Blood
Content description: Magnificent bridges are awe inspiring. But generally we marvel only at the genius of the engineers and the magnitude of the financial input, hardly appreciating the investment of human sweat and blood.

Title: Two Rare Diseases
Content description: In Hong Kong hospitals, there are as yet no specialist services for patients of rare diseases. Let’s visit two families whose sons have rare diseases.

Title: Growing Pains of Youth
Content description: Two years ago, Hong Kong Connection asked three young university graduates to each write a letter to themselves ... letters that are to be read today.  The hope was to learn more about the growing pains of youth.

Title: Our Avian Neighbours
Content description: Hong Kong is climatically attractive to birds. But as urban development continues, we invariably encroach on their natural habitats. Happily, there is growing awareness that we should co-exist with our avian neighbours.

Title: The Long Wait To See A Specialist
Content description: With over 7 million people in Hong Kong, no one should be surprised to the seemingly long queues of out-patients at public hospitals every day. Every one of them, pardon the pun, needs to be very patient.

Title: Housing For The Grassroots
Content description: Low-income people need affordable homes to live in.  To meet their pressing demand, two novel ideas have emerged: converting shipping containers into homes and getting benevolent property owners involved.

Title: Gentlemen's Battle
Content description:
Incumbent Hong Kong Bar Council chairperson Paul Lam is aggressively seeking re-election, amid a well-publicized challenge from Philip Dykes who vows to ‘stand fearlessly’ for judicial independence.
Many in the legal circles expect that the race between Lam and Dykes is going to be a tough one.  
Why does the election of a professional body catch the attention of the public?  How would the two lists of candidates prepare for the election? Will this election reflect the attitude of the Bar Council defending the city’s rule of law in coming years?

Title: Short Term Tenancies
Content description: There’s no shortage of government land that’s presently lying idle because no development plans have yet been finalised. In theory, such land can be leased to private concerns or individuals on Short Term Tenancies.

Title: I Wish I Could Fly
Content description:
This story is about the courage and determination of a girl. 
Samantha is a hearing impaired person. Unfortunately, she was also diagnosed with muscular dystrophy when she was in form 2. 
In the past year, her condition is getting worse. Samantha determines flying in the sky to enjoy the freedom and joy without being bounded by the wheelchair while she could still breathe normally. 
3 gentlemen have tried many ways, in order to help Samantha to realize her dream. But there are many hurdles in between; can she fly in the end?

Title: Short-changed
Content description: Synopsis

Title: Mending Our Ways
Content description:
Hong Kong, being an affluent, heavily populated city, produces a lot of waste. The management of plastic waste, in particular, is a huge challenge. 
But out of all the gloom and doom, encouraging signs are appearing that the public, as well as the recycling industry, are responding in a positive fashion.

Title: Low End Population
Content description:
The sage of China's "low-end population" stemmed from a huge fire in Beijing in the harsh winter of 2017. The inferno razed an apartment building on the outskirts of the Capital, killing 19 people. It prompted the Municipal Government to dismantle a host of buildings deemed illegal. Residents evicted were dubbed the “low-end population”. They’re the hordes of migrant workers who sought a better life in the nation’s capital. But they were driven out from their hearth and home, even expelled  from the city under the guise of “eliminating hidden dangers.” Residents had their water and electricity curtailed, others were forced to sleep in the streets. Some chose to return to their native villages.  Who is “low end”, who is “high end”? The issue has become a global hot topic. Some foreign media have described this as a humanitarian disaster for China.
  
Beijing artist Hua Yong was arrested by authorities for filming a documentary of the "low-end population”.  He noted Chinese people are powerless to resist tyranny but urged them to have the courage to tell the truth in order to reverse their fate.

Title: Lump Sum Grant
Content description:
The government began subsidising NGOs with lump sum grants in 2000 to replace the traditional reimbursement schemes to allow organisations more flexibility in using resources.
17 years on, the social welfare sector criticised the Lump Sum Grant as a ruse for capping resources for all services. Most NGO salaries have been decoupled from civil service salary scales, frontline staff are exploited and young social workers are changing careers.
The industry also slams the failure of the government to adjust the subsidy programme to changing times. Some services have been relying for years on private funds or the business community.
The Lump Sum Grant is now under review, a move welcomed by the social welfare sector.

Title: An Unforgettable Earthquake
Content description:
10 years ago, nearly 70,000 people died in the Wenchuan earthquake. Thousands of parents lost their children. After the quake, many people suspected shoddy construction work caused a large number of schools to collapse. Sang Jun and Liu Yuting, the parents of 2 victims, persevered in finding the truth. In the past decade, they trod the same road of appeals to the court, petitioning Beijing, and asking the media to expose the issue. But investigations still wallow in the mires.
For 10 years, they struggled between persistence and renunciation.
Will persistence bring a new dawn?
Will giving up mean the lost of all hope?

Title: A Decade Of Wounds
Content description:
The Wenchuan earthquake 10 years ago changed the lives of countless people. The temblor reaffirmed for them the impermanence of life and compelled them onto the path of rights activists.
Some parents waited 10 years hoping the authorities would erect a tombstone over a mass grave and engrave their children’s names on it. Others were jailed for probing the truth behind shoddy construction work.
Ten years of wounds that won’t heal. As the pain of the earthquake dissipates, does a new life beckon or another round of trauma?

Title: Glorifying God to Serve Man
Content description:
The Union Church at Kennedy Town has just started the redevelopment this month. The grade 3 historical building will turn a 22-storey luxurious apartment. The church collaborates with developers and will enjoy a free new church and flats that will worth more than 500 million. 

Such collaboration is not the first in Hong Kong. Another recent case is the  Shing Mun River site owned  by The Assemblies of God, applying through Town Planning Board to change the land use from open to residential buildings. Why can churches turn into apartments? We will examine issues arising from the relevant procedures and whether that will affect the overall town planning of the community.

Title: Coming of Age
Content description: This year, 2018, marks the 40 th anniversary of Hong Kong Connection. At this juncture, we thought we would revisit a few young people we interviewed 25 years ago when they were pupils in primary school to learn about their process of coming of age.

Title: The Story Of 40 Years
Content description: On this the 40 th anniversary of Hong Kong Connection, we look back on the past four decades that seem to have gone by in a flash. They will certainly be recorded as eventful years in Hong Kong’s history, with extensive coverage devoted to the change of sovereignty and the demand for democracy.

Title: A Tragic Hero
Content description: The People’s Republic of China’s national anthem, like that of any other country, is frequently heard on international occasions.  While people may be familiar with the music, perhaps not many are cognizant of the story about the man who wrote the stirring, patriotic lyrics.

Title: Mangkhut Memories
Content description:
One of the most powerful typhoons in Hong Kong’s history caused a record storm surge, uprooted trees, and continued to wreak havoc across the region. 
The city, luckily, is able to avoid serious casualties but was facing a long and difficult recovery from extensive damage.
Despite zero casualties, commuters were outrages as a result of battling huge crowds to get back to work before the transportation system back to order. 
This episode records, from citizens perspective, how the super typhoon battered the city of Hong Kong over a weekend.

Title: I See Your Beauty
Content description: Yu Mo-lin is a Hong Kong actress.She was often assigned roles such as a street cleaner, maid and unattractive woman. Her roles and personality leave a deep impression with the audience and view her as a symbol of 'ugly woman' on TV and movies in Hong Kong. In this episode, we will listen to her struggles of acting as an ugly woman whereas she always wish to be beautiful.

Title: The Book Merchant
Content description: In Hong Kong, thousands of books are published every year. There are nearly a hundred bookstores and countless publishers. Do you know more than half of the bookstores in Hong Kong come from the same enterprise? And three out of the big five publishers also come from this enterprise. Who runs this enterprise? Is it related to the Chinese government?

Title: The Eve of the Trial
Content description:
After the Umbrella Movement at 2014, the three co-founders Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man and Reverend Chu Yiu-ming, and the other six defendants include lawmakers Tanya Chan and Shiu Ka-chun, the Democratic Party’s Lee Wing-tat, the League of Social Democrats’ Raphael Wong, and former student leaders Tommy Cheung and Eason Chung.

The defendants are facing charges of inciting others to create a public nuisance, and inciting others to incite more people to create a public nuisance. And the three co-founders face an additional charge of conspiring to create a public nuisance.The trial will begin on November 19. Each charge carries a maximum sentence of seven years in jail.

Raphael Wong Ho Ming and Tommy Cheung Sau Yin well prepared before the trial.

Tommy is the youngest among the defendants. He is 24 .He join the social movement when he was in secondary school. He is the former spokesman of Scholarism, president of the Student Union of the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the standing committee of the Hong Kong Federation of Students (HKFS). He had launched campaigns against the proposed Moral and National Education. After the Umbrella Movement, he felt tired. He was no longer active in the social campaigns and turns his focus on making money. 

Raphael had been released from prison this April after a four-and-a-half month jail sentence in January for contempt after failing to comply with an injunction to clear the 2014 Umbrella Movement protest site in Mong Kok. 

Last year, he was sentenced to 13 months in jail for his involvement in the Northeast New Territories development plan demonstrations outside the legislature. He and the other twelve won the appeal on sentence before the Court of Final Appeal this September. He is an optimistic person. He believes social movement can change the society. His family are touched by his enthusiasm and turn to support him wholeheartedly.

Title: Eczema
Content description: Eczema is a long-lasting skin condition that is more than a skin deep. This is a particularly hot topic in town because this disease is one of the most common chronic childhood illnesses and there is a definite link between eczema and mental health issues.

Title: National Anthem Law
Content description:
The draft bill for the national anthem law has been submitted to the Legislative Council. It sparked concerns and criticism over the general public.
On one hand, the public says it can foster respect for the national anthem and promote patriotic spirit. But for the opposition to the draft of the bill, saying it can restrict freedom of expression and does not conform with the Basic Law. 
The reflection of national identity has been aroused again with the legislation of the national anthem law.

Title: Candle In The Wind
Content description:
Time flies, the year 2018 marks the 29th anniversary of the June Fourth Incident of 1989. Over the past 29 years, the group of victims’ family members, 'Tiananmen  Mothers' have never ceased to suffer from the grief of the loss of their loved ones. 

For over half a century, the group is frequently targeted for surveillance, harassment, and suppression as they have pressed for a reappraisal of the 1989 protests, the pursuit of those responsible, and compensation for the victims' families.  They have lived under discrimination and perceived as the “others”. They have been subjected to the monitoring of the public security organs during sensitive periods such as the 'Two Congresses,' Qingming (Tomb-sweeping Day), and June Fourth. The authorities view them as instability factors and send guards to their homes, monitor them, force them to travel, or put them under house arrests, and so on.

Twenty-eight years have gone by, Hong Kong Connection listens to the stories of the  'Tiananmen  Mothers' and how they persisted in their journey of safeguarding the dignity of the deceased and seeking justice for the victims, a thorn-filled path of untold hardships and dangers, and repeated obstructions.

Title: Creativity, Chinese Style
Content description: 2018 marks the 40th anniversary of China’s Reform and Opening (gaige kaifang) in 1978. Since then, China is an emerging economic power, and Shenzhen "Dafen Oil Painting Village" can be one of the miniatures of the whole development of China. Like most of the world factories in China, peasant-turned oil painters were exploited by entrepreneurs, yet after 40 years of development, they tried to transit from simply making copies of iconic Western paintings to creating their own authentic works of art, emblematic of the journey that China is going through, from ‘Made in China’ to ‘Created in China’. Meanwhile, the story of Dafen also put to light on how the government only focuses on economic development but neglecting human rights and freedom of the citizens while artists would like to fight for freedom of expression and speech with many difficulties.

Title: The Star-Crossed Lovers
Content description:
The love story between Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Liu Xiaobo and his widow Liu Xia was occupied by obstacles. Liu Xiaobo and Liu Xia fell in love in 1989 and they married in a prison cell. Despite years of persecution and isolation, their love endures. 
Liu Xiaobo, was diagnosed with liver cancer while still detained. His last words to his beloved wife is, “Live on well.”
After years of house arrest, Liu Xia finally liberates from the authority.

Title: Space Speculation
Content description:
If house values in Hong Kong have been rising for the past few years, then a bigger surprise would be the price of parking spaces, which have grown much faster than homes in some areas. The car parking space in Ho Man Tin, Kowloon, was sold at 6 million in June. It has become the most expensive parking space in the history of Hong Kong. The sky-high price is comparable to that of residential units.
What is the reason behind the speculation in the parking spaces? Some investors said that since the Hong Kong government launched heavy stamp duty in property market, the funds were transferred to car spaces. As a driver, our case Mr. Wong said that parking spaces are in tight supply in the territory, and the shortage of private car parking spaces is particularly severe. For instance, he and more than 500 people have to queue up, before dawn to apply for renting monthly private car parking spaces in a government car park every month.  

Last year, the Police have issued 1.84 million "fixed penalty notice"  to combat the illegal parking situation. But it seems that the provision of parking spaces is still a problem to the city. It all comes down to supply and demand. Can it be solved with better government town planning?

Title: Sub-fertility Sorrows
Content description: Infertility is a growing problem in Hong Kong. The Family planning association says one in six couples in the city suffers from infertility – a significantly increase from 20 years ago, when it was one in 10 couples. What difficulties these couples are facing and how could they seek help?

Title: The Search
Content description: A search for a missing paraglider revealed that the official search team may need to upgrade their skill sets on utilizing the already widely civil used GPS technology.

Title: Consuming Contaminants?
Content description: Plastic waste is a global problem. The United Nations Environment Programme predicts in the year of 2050, the amount of plastic waste in ocean will swell to a staggering volume of over 10 billion tonnes and surpass the total weight of sea fishes. Researches from international and local scholars already prove that microplastic beads, degraded from plastic waste in ocean, are found in sea water and some seafood, including fishes and shellfishes. Scientists are now focus on how those beads affect us when they enter the human bodies via food chain. As the initiators of all kinds of pollution on earth, will we, the homo sapiens, have a taste of our own medicine?

Title: Choosing the Chief
Content description: The Rural Representative Election was held in early 2019. Since 2003, the non-indigenous residents were allowed to run the Resident Representatives. The seats are not limited to the non-indigenous residents but also open to indigenous residents who have been lived in the village for over six years. This year, over 600 villages are involved in the election, electing 1540 seats, but many people living in rural villages have no idea about the requirements to be either a candidate, or a voter. The election is said to be lack of transparency after 15 years.

Title: Preclamation
Content description:
The Lantau Tomorrow Vision was announced and it has aroused social attention. Let us keep record the life of Peng Chau before the plan is launched. 

The Lantau Tomorrow Vision might be the last straw for fishermen. Shing started his fishing career forty years ago and he worries that no more fishing can be done under the project. 

Gary runs a local restaurant in Peng Chau. It is his family business which started in 1970. He was born in Peng Chau and grew up there too. He loves the peaceful and relaxing life there.

Title: Bridge Elegy
Content description: Online scams are rising in number and police and officials regularly warn about the risks and the need to be alert. But those searching for love and romance need to take even greater care as the fraudsters targeting dating sites and social media have perfected their charms, knowing when and how to ask questions to get their way. A lonely person can in such circumstances easily fall prey to a potential suitor who appears attractive, inviting and trusting.

Title: The Journey to the Cross
Content description: A new era for the Catholic Church in China began when Pope Francis signed off on a historic “provisional agreement” with China over the appointment of bishops. The deal broke a nearly 70-year impasse between Beijing and the Vatican.

Title: The Journey to Unity
Content description: HKCE 964

Title: Love Scam
Content description: Online scams are rising in number and police and officials regularly warn about the risks and the need to be alert. But those searching for love and romance need to take even greater care as the fraudsters targeting dating sites and social media have perfected their charms, knowing when and how to ask questions to get their way. A lonely person can in such circumstances easily fall prey to a potential suitor who appears attractive, inviting and trusting.

Title: Heaven & Earth
Content description: Hong Kong government suggests the owners of industrial buildings to convert their properties into temporary, social housing to help those living in cramped, squalid conditions, in order to make better use of industrial space. Hong Kong Connection visited two families living in the rooftop apartments and subdivided flats in factory buildings facing, telling their heartbreaking stories for eviction.

Title: Jailed on Foreign Soil
Content description:
While the president of the Philippines fights against drug dealers, four Hongkongers locked up in a Philippine prison on drug charges. The jailed men, aged 30 to 51, were arrested in Subic Bay in the Philippines in July 2016 after a raid on a “floating crystal meth laboratory”. They have denied all charges but the Philippine court ruled that four people were guilty of possession of drugs, sentenced to life imprisonment and fines. The families of the four men say they are innocent and have vowed to fight for justice. Lo Shu Ho is the sister of one of the Hong Kong residents, Lo Wing Fai. What is her story in facing all these sudden change?
The Philippine drug problem is rampant and corruption is also serious. In 2000, Tang Lung Wai went to the Phillippines and was accused of drug trafficking. He later  sentenced to life imprisonment. Meanwhile, he wrote his own experience of grievances in prison and caused social concern. Tang Lung-wai’s brother Billy thought that the incident had harmed the whole family. He didn't trust his own brother in the past and their father has even committed suicide. Will there be new hopes in the final appeal?

Title: The Last Mile of Life
Content description:
Nearly a quarter of Hong Kong people say they want to die at home, a survey shows. People believe that family can offer the best care for patients. But could they also offer a good care for the people with terminal illness? 
In this episode, we are featuring 2 families on how to prepare for their family member to die at home – a practice not yet popular in Hong Kong as about 90 per cent of deaths still take place in public hospitals.

Title: Patrick Ho's List
Content description: From a famous ophthalmologist to a capable politician, Patrick Ho was once a rising star. After leaving the SAR government as Secretary for Home Affairs, he turned himself into a civil diplomat, but was arrested in New York in late 2017 and charged with corruption and money laundering. Hong Kong Connection looks into the evidences of the trial and reconstructs the network built by Ho that covers Africa, middle America, Middle East and Eastern Europe, through a former president of the United Nations General Assembly.

Title: June Fourth
Content description: 1989 is a key turning point in world history. The Berlin Wall fell this year, triggered the domino effect on the fall of communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Poland was the first country to reject its ruling communist party through ballots on June 4th, 1989. On the same day, the People's Liberation Army cleared the student movement at the Tiananmen Square in Beijing, China. Since then, the two countries went seperate paths for 30 years.

Title: Iron Curtain
Content description:
Communist bloc faced a great change in 1989, but not perished. 
North Korea is one of the communist regime still existed with huge gestures in recent years. 
Hong Kong Connection's reporters observed this self-claimed "happiest kingdom" in close proximity.

Title: Escape
Content description:
Causeway Bay Bookstore former owner Lam Wing-kee worried that if the amendment bill on extradition law passed, the safety of Hong Kong citizens could not longer be guaranteed. At last, he chose to leave Hong Kong and stayed in Taiwan.
In 2015, Lam was detained by mainland authority for eight months. Then he was allowed to come back to Hong Kong for a short time, but he did not return as planned. 
Hong Kong Connection follows Lam's last days in Hong Kong and his first chapter in Taiwan.

Title: 721 Yuen Long Nightmare
Content description:
The police have been accused of mishandling Yuen Long's attack on 21 July. Stephen Lo, the Commissioner of Police, explained that the "delay" was due to insufficient manpower as the force was busy dealing with a protest in Hong Kong Island, as well as three cases of fight and one case of fire in the Yuen Long district. 
Hong Kong Connection's reporters have collected the CCTV footage dated 21 July from different cameras and interviewed relevant persons to reconstruct the attack's timeline and take a closer look at the police's arrangement during Yuen Long's "nightmare".

Title: Let the Voice be Heard
Content description: Over a million people took to the street on 9th June, 2019,  expressed their worries to the amendment bill of the extradition law. How the HKSAR government responds to the voices of the people? Massive protest signifies the end, or the beginning of the movement?

Title: This Early Summer
Content description: Quite a number of teenagers get involved in the campaign of anti-extradition law. Why are they so devoted and what they have experienced in the past month?

Title: Who Stole My Summer Vacation?
Content description: In the summer of 2019, the anti-extradition law rally evolved into city-wide movement. A group of young protesters took to the street and fought for their demands. When the long vacation of summer holiday comes to an end, are they prepared to put down their protective gear?

Title: Minimal Force?
Content description: Hong Kong Connection looked into the footage filmed by different media at Prince Edward MTR station on 31 August to see the appropriateness of the police's action.  It also sourced a group of citizens affected by tear gas and worked with chemical engineers to test how much toxin left around residential areas.

Title: HK People’s Sentiments For Home & Nation
Content description: OCTOBER is an anticipated month for the Chinese as they celebrate the country’s 70th birthday. While the Chinese officials announced the great achievements the country has accomplished since 1949, Hong Kong is facing the longest and largest social movement. What do Hong Kong people feel about this year national day?

Title: Remembering 1st October
Content description: Hong Kong is facing the longest and largest social movement amid the 70 years anniversary of the establishment of PRC. What will happen on October 1st?

Title: Living in Fear for Disappearing
Content description: More and more NGO members have been arrested since Jan 2019 on the Mainland. They have paid great effort to help the labor to fight for their rights and be regarded as unstable elements in the society. Not only the members suffered, their families are suffered from it too. Let’s see how tough their life is from helping those labor.

Title: Sunshine Justice?
Content description: The Judicial reform in China has been a difficult one, despite there are rigorous reform taking place since Chairman Xi Jinping took over the presidency.

Title: Searching
Content description:
Group spokeswoman of The Tiananmen Mothers, You Weijie, is constantly on the China police's radar but that doesn’t deter her from paying visit to other members of victims in other places of mainland China. Sharing the same loss of love, You has never forgotten her husband who was shot dead three decades ago during the Tiananmen Square carnage – one of the most sensitive issues for the Chinese authorities.

The Tiananmen Mothers have relentlessly continued with their demands: to know the truth, to receive compensation for the losses, and the accountability of those responsible for the mass killings whose exact figure is still unknown. However, China, which has never provided any explanation or answered to the family members, has tried hard to silence those who want to speak about the mayhem.

Title: Forgetting
Content description: 30 years ago when the internet was not common, many Hongkongers paid their respect to the student movement in Beijing through buying newspapers' ads. Hong Kong Connection traces some of these people and shares their stories about the June Fourth Incident.

Title: Marriage of Convenience
Content description: Some of the LGBT have engaged in the “marriage of convenience” in order to fulfill parents’ expectation of forming families. Marriage of convenience means that a gay is getting married with a lesbian. There is no love between them but just the title . Why do LGBT get involved in such marriage? What kind of pressure do they face now in the mainland China?

Title: Truth Is In The Eyes Of The Believer
Content description: Amid the protracted anti-extradition bill protests has emerged a plethora of online Information. Fact checking became a shared memory this summer. But the gap is increasingly widening between the "truth" in the eyes of "yellow ribbons” and "blue ribbons".  In this episode, we enter the information world of the yellows and blues to examine how the two differ.

Title: Doctor and Patient
Content description:
As the anti-extradition bill movement continues unabated, a new phenomenon appears in the medical profession: demonstrators avoiding privacy leaks are afraid to reveal their true medical conditions.
